Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season; TRAVEL Travellers urged to 
know their rights in the event of delays
Financial Times (London, England)
July 27, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 972 words
Byline: CLAER BARRETT
Body
British tourists travelling abroad this summer must navigate strike action at the UK's busiest airports and a slump in 
sterling as rising fears of a "no deal Brexit" in October put pressure on the pound.
As millions begin their summer getaway, strikes by airport workers and pilots threaten to cause disruption. Travel 
experts are urging airline customers to be aware of their rights to compensation.
Unite, the union, said up to 4,000 workers at London's Heathrow airport, including security guards and engineers, 
had called off industrial action planned for this weekend so its members could vote on a new pay offer. Without 
agreement, further strikes are planned for August 5, 6, 23 and 24.
Heathrow said it would implement contingency plans to ensure the airport remained open in the event of strikes and 
recommended passengers flying on these days contacted their airline in the days leading up to their flight to check 
its status.
At Gatwick airport, staff including baggage handlers and maintenance staff are voting on strike action this week, 
raising the potential of strikes from mid-August.
A planned strike by easyJet check-in staff at Stansted airport was suspended this week while Unite members voted 
on a new pay deal.
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
Thousands of passengers flying with British Airways this summer could be affected by strikes planned by pilots in a 
dispute over pay. This week, the UK's flagship carrier failed to obtain an injunction to prevent the strike and will now 
take its case to the Court of Appeal.
Balpa, the British Airline Pilots Association, confirmed it would not announce strike dates until after the appeal is 
heard, and is required to give two weeks' notice of industrial action, meaning that the earliest a strike could 
startwouldbeAugust 13.
The strike would affect flights to and from London Heathrow and Gatwick, but not BA's CityFlyer services 
fromLondonCity airport .
BA urged passengers to check its website for updates and ensure that contact details in the "Manage my booking" 
area of the sitewereuptodate.
Ryanair pilots are separately being balloted for strike action bythe Irish Airline Pilots Associationbut the outcome will 
notbeknownuntilAugust9.
Passengers whose TRAVEL plans are affected by strikedisruption have limited rights to compensation under EU 
rules governing flight delays, as these are seen as "extraordinarycircumstances".
Simon Calder of the BBC's The TRAVEL Show said European air passengers' rights rules stipulate compensation 
of (EURO)250 to (EURO)600 for flights that arrive three hours or morebehind schedule.
The payout applies for all flights from an EU airport and for departures from outside EuropeonanEUairline .
"Thecause 
of 
the 
delaymust 
be 
within 
the 
airline's 
control, 
rather 
than 
an 
'extraordinary 
circumstance'suchasweather, a security alert or staff shortages at air-traffic control - a particular problem this 
summer,"hesays.
"Some airlines will readily pay out for delays, but others will defend claims robustly."
"Whatever the cause of the delay, airlines must provide an alternative flight as soon as possible, on a rival carrier if 
need be, as well as meals and accommodation while the passenger is stranded."
Salman Haqqi, personal finance expert www.atMoney.co.uk, added that TRAVELlershadmore rights to 
compensation. if delays were due to an airline's ownstaff going on strike .
"This industrial action is the responsibility of the airline and 'extraordinary circumstance' cannot be cited as a 
reason,"he says.
"If airline staff strike and your flight to or fromtheUKis cancelled, under EU regulations, you are entitled to a full 
refund; or an alternative flight to your destination from a nearbyairport, with the airline responsible for additional 
costs; or a flight on a later date outside the strikeperiod.
"However, this will be scant consolation for many holidaymakers, as the likelihood of being able to book on to an 
alternative flight during this peakperiod willbeslim.
"Check your TRAVEL insurance, as you may be able to claim for a cancelled or delayed flight - provided you took 
the policy out before the strikes were announced," said MrHaqqi.
Passengers who do jet off would be well advised to avoid changing holidaymoneyat the airport .
During July, sterling has fallen by about 2 per cent against the dollar, but the pound reached parity against the 
dollar and the euro in most airport exchange booths some time ago, meaning TRAVELlers will receive less than 
(EURO)1 or $1 for every pound they exchange.
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
A study by FairFX, the holiday money specialist, found that exchange rates offered at UK airports were up to 21 per 
cent lower than the best market rate. Holidaymakers who leave changing money until the last minute could lose out 
by as much as (EURO)121 for every£500exchanged.
The Post Office warned that tourists using their bank cards abroad could be hit by unexpected charges costing the 
average family£120.UKbanks typically charge 3 per cent of the transaction value for overseas card transactions and 
ATMwithdrawals.
Digital challenger banks such as Starling, Monzo and Revolut waive these charges, and have rapid online account 
opening facilities for those about to Travel.
Certain credit cards also offer fee-free spending abroad - although if credit cards are used to withdraw cash froman 
ATM, interest will typically be charged fromthatday.
Finally, even TRAVELlers savvy enough to get a fee-free card should watch out for chip and pin terminals or 
cashpoints that ask if they want to pay in pounds rather than the local currency.
Known as "dynamic currency conversion", this allows the merchant to set the exchangerate.
"It's unlikely the rate they decide on will be in your favour," said Ian Strafford-Taylor, chief executive of FairFX.
A recent investigation by FairFX found that unsuspecting holidaymakers collectively paid out £490m in currency 
conversion fees.
Graphic
 
Know your rights in the event of flight delays - Getty
Load-Date: July 27, 2019
End of Document

delays

During July, sterling has fallen by about 2 per cent against the dollar, but the pound reached parity against the 
dollar and the euro in most airport exchange booths some time ago, meaning TRAVELlers will receive less than 
(EURO)1 or $1 for every pound they exchange.
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
A study by FairFX, the holiday money specialist, found that exchange rates offered at UK airports were up to 21 per 
cent lower than the best market rate. Holidaymakers who leave changing money until the last minute could lose out 
by as much as (EURO)121 for every£500exchanged.
The Post Office warned that tourists using their bank cards abroad could be hit by unexpected charges costing the 
average family£120.UKbanks typically charge 3 per cent of the transaction value for overseas card transactions and 
ATMwithdrawals.
Digital challenger banks such as Starling, Monzo and Revolut waive these charges, and have rapid online account 
opening facilities for those about to Travel.
Certain credit cards also offer fee-free spending abroad - although if credit cards are used to withdraw cash froman 
ATM, interest will typically be charged fromthatday.
Finally, even TRAVELlers savvy enough to get a fee-free card should watch out for chip and pin terminals or 
cashpoints that ask if they want to pay in pounds rather than the local currency.
Known as "dynamic currency conversion", this allows the merchant to set the exchangerate.
"It's unlikely the rate they decide on will be in your favour," said Ian Strafford-Taylor, chief executive of FairFX.
A recent investigation by FairFX found that unsuspecting holidaymakers collectively paid out £490m in currency 
conversion fees.
Graphic
 
Know your rights in the event of flight delays - Getty

End of Document
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season; TRAVEL Travellers urged to 
know their rights in the event of delays
Financial Times (London, England)
July 27, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;NEWS; Pg. 3
Length: 972 words
Byline: CLAER BARRETT
Body
British tourists travelling abroad this summer must navigate strike action at the UK's busiest airports and a slump in 
sterling as rising fears of a "no deal Brexit" in October put pressure on the pound.
As millions begin their summer getaway, strikes by airport workers and pilots threaten to cause disruption. Travel 
experts are urging airline customers to be aware of their rights to compensation.
Unite, the union, said up to 4,000 workers at London's Heathrow airport, including security guards and engineers, 
had called off industrial action planned for this weekend so its members could vote on a new pay offer. Without 
agreement, further strikes are planned for August 5, 6, 23 and 24.
Heathrow said it would implement contingency plans to ensure the airport remained open in the event of strikes and 
recommended passengers flying on these days contacted their airline in the days leading up to their flight to check 
its status.
At Gatwick airport, staff including baggage handlers and maintenance staff are voting on strike action this week, 
raising the potential of strikes from mid-August.
A planned strike by easyJet check-in staff at Stansted airport was suspended this week while Unite members voted 
on a new pay deal.
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
Thousands of passengers flying with British Airways this summer could be affected by strikes planned by pilots in a 
dispute over pay. This week, the UK's flagship carrier failed to obtain an injunction to prevent the strike and will now 
take its case to the Court of Appeal.
Balpa, the British Airline Pilots Association, confirmed it would not announce strike dates until after the appeal is 
heard, and is required to give two weeks' notice of industrial action, meaning that the earliest a strike could 
startwouldbeAugust 13.
The strike would affect flights to and from London Heathrow and Gatwick, but not BA's CityFlyer services 
fromLondonCity airport .
BA urged passengers to check its website for updates and ensure that contact details in the "Manage my booking" 
area of the sitewereuptodate.
Ryanair pilots are separately being balloted for strike action bythe Irish Airline Pilots Associationbut the outcome will 
notbeknownuntilAugust9.
Passengers whose TRAVEL plans are affected by strikedisruption have limited rights to compensation under EU 
rules governing flight delays, as these are seen as "extraordinarycircumstances".
Simon Calder of the BBC's The TRAVEL Show said European air passengers' rights rules stipulate compensation 
of (EURO)250 to (EURO)600 for flights that arrive three hours or morebehind schedule.
The payout applies for all flights from an EU airport and for departures from outside EuropeonanEUairline .
"Thecause 
of 
the 
delaymust 
be 
within 
the 
airline's 
control, 
rather 
than 
an 
'extraordinary 
circumstance'suchasweather, a security alert or staff shortages at air-traffic control - a particular problem this 
summer,"hesays.
"Some airlines will readily pay out for delays, but others will defend claims robustly."
"Whatever the cause of the delay, airlines must provide an alternative flight as soon as possible, on a rival carrier if 
need be, as well as meals and accommodation while the passenger is stranded."
Salman Haqqi, personal finance expert www.atMoney.co.uk, added that TRAVELlershadmore rights to 
compensation. if delays were due to an airline's ownstaff going on strike .
"This industrial action is the responsibility of the airline and 'extraordinary circumstance' cannot be cited as a 
reason,"he says.
"If airline staff strike and your flight to or fromtheUKis cancelled, under EU regulations, you are entitled to a full 
refund; or an alternative flight to your destination from a nearbyairport, with the airline responsible for additional 
costs; or a flight on a later date outside the strikeperiod.
"However, this will be scant consolation for many holidaymakers, as the likelihood of being able to book on to an 
alternative flight during this peakperiod willbeslim.
"Check your TRAVEL insurance, as you may be able to claim for a cancelled or delayed flight - provided you took 
the policy out before the strikes were announced," said MrHaqqi.
Passengers who do jet off would be well advised to avoid changing holidaymoneyat the airport .
During July, sterling has fallen by about 2 per cent against the dollar, but the pound reached parity against the 
dollar and the euro in most airport exchange booths some time ago, meaning TRAVELlers will receive less than 
(EURO)1 or $1 for every pound they exchange.
Strikes and weak sterling blight holiday season TRAVEL Travellers urged to know their rights in the event of 
delays
A study by FairFX, the holiday money specialist, found that exchange rates offered at UK airports were up to 21 per 
cent lower than the best market rate. Holidaymakers who leave changing money until the last minute could lose out 
by as much as (EURO)121 for every£500exchanged.
The Post Office warned that tourists using their bank cards abroad could be hit by unexpected charges costing the 
average family£120.UKbanks typically charge 3 per cent of the transaction value for overseas card transactions and 
ATMwithdrawals.
Digital challenger banks such as Starling, Monzo and Revolut waive these charges, and have rapid online account 
opening facilities for those about to Travel.
Certain credit cards also offer fee-free spending abroad - although if credit cards are used to withdraw cash froman 
ATM, interest will typically be charged fromthatday.
Finally, even TRAVELlers savvy enough to get a fee-free card should watch out for chip and pin terminals or 
cashpoints that ask if they want to pay in pounds rather than the local currency.
Known as "dynamic currency conversion", this allows the merchant to set the exchangerate.
"It's unlikely the rate they decide on will be in your favour," said Ian Strafford-Taylor, chief executive of FairFX.
A recent investigation by FairFX found that unsuspecting holidaymakers collectively paid out £490m in currency 
conversion fees.

https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgBidaskClub[1] 
upgraded 
shares 
of 
Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) from a strong sell rating to a sell rating in a report issued on Tuesday, BidAskClub[2] 
reports.RYAAY has been the subject of several other research reports. Canaccord Genuity reissued a buy rating 
and set a $1.80 price target on shares of Meridian Bioscience in a research report on Wednesday, June 5th. 
ValuEngine[3] raised shares of Zynerba Pharmaceuticals from a sell rating to a hold rating in a research report on 
Monday, April 1st. HSBC set a €9.00 ($10.47) price target on shares of Schaeffler and gave the company a buy 
rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 22nd. JPMorgan Chase .... set a €20.00 ($23.26) price target on 
shares of STMicroelectronics and gave the company a buy rating in a research report on Tuesday, May 21st. 
Finally, Deutsche Bank set a $261.00 price target on shares of Vail Resorts and gave the company a buy rating in a 
research report on Friday, June 7th. Six research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have 
assigned a hold rating and seven have issued a buy rating to the stock. The company currently has an average 
rating of Hold and a consensus target price of $75.33.Shares of RYAAY[4] opened at $63.63 on Tuesday. The 
stock has a market cap of $15.20 billion, a PE ratio of 12.38 and a beta of 0.79. The company has a quick ratio of 
0.93, a current ratio of 0.93 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.64. The firm's fifty day moving average price is $64.68. 
Ryanair has a twelve month low of $60.83 and a twelve month high of $110.08. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last 
announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, May 20th. The transportation company reported ($0.74) 
earnings per share for the quarter, missing the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($0.64) by ($0.10). The 
firm had revenue of $1.45 billion for the quarter. Ryanair had a net margin of 11.69% and a return on equity of 
20.34%. On average, analysts predict that Ryanair will post 4.05 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.

during the 1st quarter. BB...orp now owns 4,419 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $331,000 
after acquiring an additional 299 shares during the period. Baldwin Investment Management LLC lifted its position in 
Ryanair by 3.3% during the 1st quarter. Baldwin Investment Management LLC now owns 9,341 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $700,000 after acquiring an additional 300 shares during the period.

Scout Investments Inc. Has $19.01 Million Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Scout Investments Inc. Has $19.01 Million Position in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
July 25, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 718 words
Body
Ryanair logo Scout Investments Inc. grew its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 9.1% in the 
2nd quarter, according to its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The institutional 
investor  owned 296,449 shares of the transportation company's stock after buying an additional 24,846 shares 
during the quarter. Scout Investments Inc. owned 0.13% of Ryanair worth $19,014,000 as of its most recent SEC 
filing.  
Other large investors have also recently modified their holdings of the company. Baldwin Investment Management 
LLC raised its position in shares of  Ryanair by 3.3% in the 1st quarter. Baldwin Investment Management LLC now 
owns 9,341 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $700,000 after buying an additional 300 shares 
in the last quarter.  BB&T Corp increased its position in  Ryanair by 7.3% during the 1st quarter. BB&T Corp now 
owns 4,419 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $331,000 after purchasing an additional 299 shares 
in the last quarter.  First Pacific Advisors LP increased its position in  Ryanair by 9.3% during the 1st quarter. First 
Pacific Advisors LP now owns 78,303 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $5,868,000 after 
purchasing an additional 6,690 shares in the last quarter.  Brinker Capital Inc. increased its position in  Ryanair by 
26.5% during the 1st quarter. Brinker Capital Inc. now owns 28,668 shares of the transportation company's stock 
worth $2,148,000 after purchasing an additional 6,009 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Two Sigma Investments 
LP acquired a new position in  Ryanair during the 4th quarter worth approximately $4,195,000. Institutional 
investors own  43.21% of the company's stock.  
RYAAY  traded down $1.01 during trading on Thursday, reaching $63.88. 344,762 shares of the company's stock 
were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 750,166. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $60.83 
and a one year high of $110.08. The company has a quick ratio of 0.93, a current ratio of 0.93 and a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 0.64. The stock has a market capitalization of $15.30 billion, a PE ratio of 12.43 and a beta of 0.79. The 
stock has a fifty day moving average price of $64.75.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its earnings results on Monday, May 20th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.74) earnings per share for the quarter, missing the Zacks' consensus estimate of ($0.64) by ($0.10). 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 20.34% and a net margin of 11.69%. The business had revenue of $1.45 billion 
for the quarter.  As a group, equities research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 4.05 earnings 
per share for the current year.  
Scout Investments Inc. Has $19.01 Million Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
A number of research firms recently issued reports on RYAAY. Canaccord Genuity  reiterated a "buy" rating and set 
a $1.80 price objective on shares of Meridian Bioscience in a research report on Wednesday, June 5th. Raymond 
James  reiterated a "hold" rating on shares of PrairieSky Royalty in a research report on Thursday, July 11th. Credit 
Suisse Group lowered their price objective on shares of Lennox International from $282.00 to $265.00 and set a 
"neutral" rating for the company in a research report on Tuesday. ValuEngine  upgraded shares of Zynerba 
Pharmaceuticals from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Monday, April 1st. Finally, BidaskClub 
cut shares of YY from a "sell" rating to a "strong sell" rating in a research report on Tuesday. Six research analysts 
have rated the stock with a sell rating, three have issued  a hold rating and seven have given a buy rating to the 
company. The stock currently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $75.33. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Financial Times (London, England)
July 25, 2019 Thursday

Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 22

Ryanair Portuguese Cabin Crew to Strike in August Over Pay, Conditions
Ryanair Portuguese Cabin Crew to Strike in August Over Pay, Conditions
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 25, 2019 Thursday 5:28 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 104 words
Body
 Ryanair's (RYAAY) cabin crew union, the National Union of Civil Aviation Flight Personnel (SNPVAC), is calling for 
a  strike in August over the Irish low-cost carrier's alleged failure to comply with agreed terms on holiday pay and 
certain working conditions, Reuters said late Wednesday.
According to the report, SNPVAC accused Ryanair of refusing to hold to its end of the bargain, which included 
granting holiday pay, 22 days of annual leave per year and full compliance with Portuguese parental law.
SNPVAC has not decided on the schedule of the strike yet, the report said. 
Price: 64.89, Change: -0.44, Percent Change: -0.67
Load-Date: July 26, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Portuguese cabin crew to strike in August
Ryanair Portuguese cabin crew to strike in August
Business World (Digest)
July 25, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 197 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair cabin crew in Portugal are set to strike for five days in August in a dispute over pay and conditions, the 
SNPVAC union said on Wednesday.
The industrial action comes as Ryanair pilots in Ireland and the United Kingdom are holding ballots on a possible 
strike action in August. SNPVAC said it had not yet decided which days in August it would strike.
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost carrier, suffered a series of damaging strikes last year.
Management say significant progress has been made since, with collective labour agreements concluded with a 
number of pilot unions throughout Europe.
But SNPVAC said Ryanair has refused to comply with a protocol signed last November, which it said included 
holiday pay, 22 days of annual leave per year and full compliance with Portuguese parental law.
"Facing the intransigence from Ryanair and the lack of interest of the Portuguese government on guaranteeing the 
fundamental labour rights to their citizens that work for Ryanair, the cabin crew had no other choice but to return to 
the industrial conflict," SNPVAC said in a statement.
Ryanair did not immediately respond to a request for comment. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: August 21, 2019

European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 23, 2019 Tuesday 10:30 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 232 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.42% higher at 1,054.71 on the BNY Mellon 
Europe Select ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company MorphoSys (MOR) and bank Banco 
Santander (SAN), which rose 3.9% and 3.4% respectively. They were followed by computer hardware accessories 
maker Logitech (LOGI) and bank Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), which were up 3.3% and 2.7%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by dating app operator Spark Networks (LOV) and biopharmaceutical 
company argenx (ARGX), which fell 4.2% and 1.8% respectively. They were followed by 3D printer maker voxeljet 
(VJET) and pharmaceutical firm Novo Nordisk (NVO), which lost 1.6% each.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by cruise line operator Carnival (CUK) and telecommunications operator 
BT Group (BT), which rose 2.7% and 2% respectively. They were followed by Barclays Bank (BCS) and 
telecommunications operator Vodafone Group (VOD), which were up 1.8% and 1.7%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biotech firm Autolus Therapeutics (AUTL) and airline operator 
Ryanair (RYAAY), which lost 2.4% and 1.2% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical companies 
GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH) and Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which were off 0.7% and 0.3%.

Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Delayed deliveries and 'uncertain return' drive base closures
Delayed deliveries and 'uncertain return' drive base closures
Flight International
July 23, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: THIS WEEK
Length: 156 words
Body
Operation “remains uncertain”, although it still believes this will happen before the end of the year.It points out, 
however, that the high-density version of the jet – the configuration ordered by Ryanair – will require separate 
certification and that this could take another two months after the Max is cleared.“Boeing is hoping that a 
certification package will be submitted to regulators by September with a return to service shortly thereafter,” says 
Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary.“We believe it would be prudent to plan for that date to slip by some 
months, possibly as late as December.”The delivery of 30 rather than 58 aircraft ahead of the summer season 
means the budget airline has revised its summer capacity expansion plan, cutting it back from 7% to 3%.“This 
shortfall in aircraft deliveries will necessitate some base cuts and closures for summer 2020, but also for the winter 
2019 schedule,” warns the carrier.

European ADRs Move Lower in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 22, 2019 Monday 10:34 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 238 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.16% lower at 1,046.94 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by electronics maker Philips Electronics (PHG) and biotech firm 
Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), which climbed 5.5% and 2% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical 
company Cellectis (CLLS) and semiconductor company STMicroelectronics (STM), which rose 1.7% each.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and 
internet browser company Opera (OPRA), which ell 3% and 2.7% respectively. They were followed by dating app 
operator Spark Networks (LOV), and bank Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), which dropped 2.4% and 
1.1%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY) and educational publisher Pearson 
(PSO), which rose 2.1% and 1.5% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company Amarin 
(AMRN) and software firm Endava (DAVA), which were up 1.1% and 0.7%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical firm Akari Therapeutics (AKTX) and specialty 
pharmaceuticals company Motif Bio (MTFB), which fell 13.3% and 5.8% respectively. They were followed by 
telecommunications operator BT Group (BT) and alcoholics beverage company Diageo (DEO), which were off 1.7% 
and 0.9%.
Price: 45.93, Change: +2.42, Percent Change: +5.56
Load-Date: July 23, 2019
European ADRs Move Lower in Monday Trading

Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" 
by Analysts
American Banking and Market News
July 19, 2019 Friday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 644 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) has earned an average rating of "Hold" from the sixteen 
brokerages that are presently  covering the firm,            MarketBeat Ratings  reports. Five research analysts have 
rated the stock with a sell rating, three have assigned  a hold rating and seven have given a buy rating to  the 
company. The average twelve-month target price among analysts that have updated their coverage on the stock in 
the last year is $76.50.  
A number of research firms have recently weighed in on RYAAY. ValuEngine  upgraded Zynerba Pharmaceuticals 
from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Monday, April 1st. Raymond James  restated a "hold" 
rating on shares of PrairieSky Royalty in a research report on Thursday, July 11th. BidaskClub downgraded Zebra 
Technologies from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Tuesday. HSBC  set a  9.00 ($10.47) 
target price on Schaeffler and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 22nd. Finally, 
Deutsche Bank  set a $261.00 target price on Vail Resorts and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research report on 
Friday, June 7th. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  opened at $64.62 on Friday. The company has a current ratio of 0.93, a quick ratio of 0.93 
and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.64. The firm has a market cap of $15.14 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 12.57 and 
a beta of 0.79. The company has a fifty day moving average of $64.88. Ryanair has a one year low of $60.83 and a 
one year high of $118.23.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, May 20th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.74) EPS for the quarter, missing analysts' consensus estimates of ($0.64) by ($0.10). The 
business had revenue of $1.45 billion during the quarter. Ryanair had a return on equity of 20.34% and a net 
margin of 11.69%.  As a group, research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair will post 4.05 EPS for the current year.  
Several hedge funds have recently added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. Baldwin Investment Management 
LLC increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 3.3% in the first quarter. Baldwin Investment Management LLC now owns 
9,341 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $700,000 after purchasing an additional 300 shares 
during the last quarter.  BB&T Corp increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 7.3% in the first quarter. BB&T Corp now 
owns 4,419 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $331,000 after purchasing an additional 299 
shares during the last quarter.  First Pacific Advisors LP increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 9.3% in the first 
quarter. First Pacific Advisors LP now owns 78,303 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$5,868,000 after purchasing an additional 6,690 shares during the last quarter.  Brinker Capital Inc. increased its 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Given Consensus Rating of "Hold" by Analysts
holdings in  Ryanair by 26.5% in the first quarter. Brinker Capital Inc. now owns 28,668 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $2,148,000 after purchasing an additional 6,009 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, 
Two Sigma Investments LP bought a new stake in  Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at about $4,195,000. 
Institutional investors own  43.19% of the company's stock.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website. 
See Also: New Google Finance Tool and Screening Stocks

Ryanair 's Bellew flies to EasyJet Airlines
Ryanair's Bellew flies to EasyJet; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
July 19, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 226 words
Byline: JANINA CONBOYE
Body
EasyJet has hired rival Ryanair's operations chief Peter Bellew, a 30-year industry veteran, as it navigates intense 
competition in the European short-haul market.
The airline announced Mr Bellew's appointment as chief operating officer alongside a trading update that revealed 
an 11 per cent rise in revenue for the latest quarter.
EasyJet said a strong Easter and a reduction in long delays and cancellations had helped boost total revenue to 
£1.76bn in the three months to June. Passenger revenue rose 10.7 per cent to £1.39bn.
The low-cost carrier said it that expected to deliver a profit before tax of between £400m and £440m in the second 
half, in line with market expectations.
Mr Bellew spent nine years at Ryanair, where he held roles including director of flight operations, before he left for 
Malaysia Airlines, where he was eventually named chief executive. He rejoined Ryanair in December 2017, 
following a pilot rostering crisis at the Irish carrier that led to the cancellation of 2,000 flights.
Johan Lundgren, chief executive of easyJet, said Mr Bellow had an "exceptional level of experience" in low-cost 
and full-service airlines and was "a great leader with a proven track record in delivering results".
Mr Bellew said easyJet had a great product with an enviable position at many of Europe's primary airports. It had 
"always been an innovator".
Ryanair 's Bellew flies to EasyJet Airlines
Load-Date: July 18, 2019
End of Document

https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgBidaskClub[1] downgraded shares of Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) from a sell rating to a strong sell rating in a research report released on Tuesday, BidAskClub[2]

a market cap of $14.96 billion, a P/E ratio of 12.57 and a beta of 0.79. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced 
its quarterly earnings data on Monday, May 20th. The transportation company reported ($0.74) earnings per share 
(EPS) for the quarter, missing the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($0.64) by ($0.10). The business had 
revenue of $1.45 billion during the quarter. Ryanair had a return on equity of 20.34% and a net margin of 11.69%.

Easyjet revenue takes off during 'robust' quarter
Easyjet revenue takes off during 'robust' quarter
City A.M.
July 19, 2019 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 9
Length: 189 words
Byline: JOE CURTIS
Body
EASYJET boosted revenue 11 per cent to £1.8bn in its third quarter, the airline revealed yesterday, saying it is on 
schedule to hit market expectations on profit.
The airline also posted higher passenger revenue, growing that 10.7 per cent year on year to record £1.4bn.
Ancillary revenue rose 14.3 per cent to £374m.
Meanwhile, the number of passengers rose by 2m to hit 26m for the quarter.
Chief executive Johan Lundgren hailed the solid quarter's trading and said the flyer should deliver profit before tax 
of between £400m and £440m.
However, "softening demand" due to macroeconomic uncertainty across Europe and Brexit-related consumer 
uncertainty hurt Easyjet.
It also pointed to headwinds from Monarch Airlines' and Air Berlin's bankruptcies, and France's so-called yellow 
vest protests, as challenges.
The firm expects to hit its full-year targets, including growing full-year capacity by 10 per cent, though second-half 
revenue will be slightly down, as per its earlier guidance.
Meanwhile, the budget airline also appointed ex-Ryanair executive Peter Bellew as chief operating officer.
Shares ticked up 4.01 per cent to close at 1,076p.
Easyjet revenue takes off during 'robust' quarter
Load-Date: July 19, 2019
End of Document
TOP NEWS: easyJet Poaches Ryanair Operating Chief Amid Revenue Rise
TOP NEWS: easyJet Poaches Ryanair Operating Chief Amid Revenue Rise
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
July 18, 2019 Thursday 3:38 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 445 words
Body
 Budget airline easyJet PLC said on Thursday that third quarter revenue rose year-on-year, partly due to the Easter 
period being in the second half of the current financial year.
easyJet also announced it has poached the chief operating officer of market rival Ryanair Holdings PLC to take on 
the same role at easyJet. COO Peter Bellew had rejoined Ryanair in late 2017, having been chief executive officer 
of Malaysia Airlines. He previously had been had been director of flight operations for Ryanair until 2014. 
easyJet reported total revenue for the third quarter ended June 30 of GBP1.76 billion, an 11% year-on-year rise on 
2018's GBP1.51 billion. 
The airline said the later Easter in 2019, which generated almost GBP40.0 million extra, and an accounting change, 
which had a revenue benefit of GBP10.0 million, helped drive the third quarter growth. 
easyJet said ancillary revenue, which is the money it generates from baggage charges and on-board catering, grew 
by 14% year-on-year to GBP374.0 million from GBP328.0 million.
Passengers flown in the quarter rose to 26.4 million from 24.4 million a year before, with third-quarter revenue per 
seat also increased year-on-year to GBP61.22 from GBP60.44.
The company said the revenue gain was partially offset by weak market conditions, particularly in Europe due to 
Brexit-related consumer uncertainty. 
easyJet's cost per seat fell year-on-year, by 0.5% to GBP55.16 from GBP55.45. It attributed the reduction to fewer 
costly delays and the wet leasing of fewer aircraft. It also had fewer cancellations in the third quarter this year, 847 
compared with 2,606.
Looking ahead, the airline predicted pretax profit for the financial year ending September 30 to be between 
GBP400.0 million and GBP440.0 million, in line with market expectations. It would however be slightly below 
financial 2018's pretax profit of GBP445 million.
TOP NEWS: easyJet Poaches Ryanair Operating Chief Amid Revenue Rise
Chief Executive Johan Lundgren said: "easyJet's third quarter performance was robust and despite the tougher 
macroeconomic conditions was in line with expectations. Revenue increased by over 11% with revenue per seat 
increasing through a combination of successful revenue initiatives, a solid Easter performance and a focus on late 
yield initiatives, with passenger numbers climbing by two million to over 26 million. 
"Our customers experienced significantly reduced cancellations and long delays largely as a result of our 
investment in operational resilience, which also contributed significantly to driving down cost per seat ex fuel at 
constant currency by 4% in the period." 
easyJet shares were up 3.6% at 1,071.50 pence each in London on Thursday morning. Ryanair was trading flat at 
EUR10.50.
Load-Date: July 19, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair 's British pilot union to vote on possible August strike
Ryanair's British pilot union to vote on possible August strike
Business World (Digest)
July 18, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND; World
Length: 356 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair's British pilot union is to ballot members on possible strike action in coming weeks in a dispute over 
working conditions, the British Airline Pilots Association (BALPA) announced on Wednesday.
The results of the ballot are due on August 7 and strike action by pilots in the airline's largest market could take 
place two weeks later, the union told members in a memo, which has been seen by Reuters.
The ballot is a setback for management at Europe's largest low-cost carrier, who have in recent months said they 
had largely resolved an industrial relations dispute with pilots and cabin crew.
Ryanair suffered a series of damaging strikes last year after the carrier bowed to pressure in late 2017 to recognize 
unions for the first time. But since then it has signed collective labor agreements with a number of pilot unions 
throughout Europe.
BALPA General Secretary Brian Strutton said in a statement that no progress had been made in talks on issues 
including pensions, maternity benefits and "a fair, transparent, and consistent pay structure."
"We have not been able to make any progress with Ryanair at all on any of our areas of concern," Strutton said.
In the memo, BALPA said its members in a consultative ballot had overwhelmingly supported the move to hold a 
vote on strike action.
It said it understood that pilot union colleagues in Spain, Ireland, Sweden and Germany had made "little, if any, 
meaningful progress" in talks with Ryanair.
Ryanair 's British pilot union to vote on possible August strike
Ryanair, which says it offers some of the best conditions for low-cost short-haul Boeing pilots in Europe, did not 
immediately respond to a request for comment.
Chief Marketing Officer Kenny Jacobs earlier on Wednesday said he hoped to sign collective labor agreements with 
Germany's Vereinigung Cockpit pilot union by the end of August, adding that he did not expect strikes anywhere in 
Europe.
On Tuesday, Ryanair said it had been forced to halve its growth plans for 2020 due to delays in the delivery of 
Boeing's grounded 737 MAX jet and planned to start talks with airports and unions about downsizing or closing 
some operations from November 2019. (Reuters)
Source:www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: August 12, 2019
End of Document

EasyJet Q3 Revenue Rises; Peter Bellew Named COO - Quick Facts
EasyJet Q3 Revenue Rises; Peter Bellew Named COO - Quick Facts
RTT News (United States)
July 18, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 284 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Low-cost airline easyJet Plc (ESYJY.PK, EZJ.L) reported Thursday that its third-quarter total revenue 
increased 11.4 percent from the year-ago period to 1.76 billion pounds.
 Passenger revenue for the quarter increased by 10.7 percent to 1.39 billion pounds and ancillary revenue 
increased by 14.3 percent to 374 million pounds.
 Passenger numbers in the third quarter increased 8 percent to 26.4 million, driven by an increase in capacity of 10 
percent to 28.8 million seats. 
 Load factor decreased, as anticipated, by 1.7 percentage points to 91.7 percent, due to late yield initiatives as well 
as high prior-year comparatives due to industrial action in France and Monarch's bankruptcy.
 Total revenue per seat increased 0.7 percent at constant currency, including a strong late yield performance which 
benefited from easyJet's revenue initiatives as well as positive ancillary revenue growth and a solid Easter 
performance.
 Looking ahead to fiscal 2019, easyJet forecast its headline profit before tax to be between 400 million pounds and 
440 million pounds, in line with market expectations. The company also affirmed its outlook for full-year capacity to 
grow by about 10 percent.
 Further, easyJet maintained its outlook for second-half revenue per seat at constant currency to be slightly down, 
and capacity to grow by about 7 percent.
 easyJet also said that Peter Bellew will join the company as Chief Operating Officer.  He will be a member of the 
Airline Management Board and will report to easyJet's CEO, Johan Lundgren.
EasyJet Q3 Revenue Rises; Peter Bellew Named COO - Quick Facts
 Bellew joins the airline from Ryanair where he has been Chief Operations Officer since December 2017, 
responsible for all aspects of Ryanair's flight operations.        
Load-Date: July 18, 2019
End of Document
EasyJet names former Ryanair executive Bellew as operations chief UK low-cost carrier EasyJet has appointed 
former Ryanair executive Peter Bellew as its new chi....
EasyJet names former Ryanair executive Bellew as operations chief; UK 
low-cost carrier EasyJet has appointed former Ryanair executive Peter 
Bellew as its new chief operating officer, it disclosed today as it reported 
"robust" third-quarter trading.
Flight International
July 18, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 336 words
Body
UK low-cost carrier EasyJet has appointed former Ryanair executive Peter Bellew as its new chief operating officer, 
it disclosed today as it reported "robust" third-quarter trading.
EasyJet chief Johan Lundgren says Bellew's experience at both low-cost and full-service carriers – he served a 
stint as Malaysia Airlines' chief executive – meant he would be a "great addition" to the team.
Bellew is leaving Ryanair at the end of the year, but it is not yet confirmed when he would take up his new role at 
EasyJet, says Lundgren.
In a trading update, EasyJet says total revenue for the three months to 30 June rose 11% to £1.76 billion ($2.16 
billion), while revenue per seat rose 0.7% at constant currency.
The airline highlights that it brought cost per seat excluding fuel down by 4% at constant currency in the quarter.
"Our customers experienced significantly less disruption aided by our investments in resilience, with two-thirds less 
cancellations in the period helping to drive costs down," notes Lundgren.
EasyJet also says it is benefiting from more capacity discipline in the market, with rivals growing capacity 3.4% 
across its network. That compares with EasyJet's full-year capacity growth of 10%, unchanged from its last update.
"Make no mistake, it is still tough out there," says Lundgren. EasyJet expects second-half headline revenue per 
seat will be slightly down. .
EasyJet names former Ryanair executive Bellew as operations chief UK low-cost carrier EasyJet has appointed 
former Ryanair executive Peter Bellew as its new chi....
However, Lundgren says he is pleased with the late-booking environment and adds that EasyJet has taken 
measures to improve late yields, such as getting more detailed information on pricing on a route-by-route basis via 
better data analysis and algorithms.
It says it expects to deliver a full-year profit before tax of £400-440 million, which it describes as in line with market 
expectations. For the 2018/19 financial year, it made a profit of £578 million.
For the current financial year it expects a total fuel bill of £1.4 billion and foresees that foreign-exchange 
movements will have a £5 million adverse impact on headline pretax profit.

Setback for Ryanair as UK pilots poised for ballot on strike action
Setback for Ryanair as UK pilots poised for ballot on strike action
City A.M.
July 18, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 160 words
Byline: CONOR HUMPHRIES
Body
RYANAIR's British pilot union is to ballot members on possible strike action over working conditions, the British 
Airline Pilots Association (Balpa) announced yesterday.
The results are due on 7 August and action by pilots in the airline's largest market could take place two weeks later, 
the union told members in a memo seen by Reuters.
The ballot is a setback for management at Europe's largest lowcost carrier, who recently said they had largely 
resolved a dispute with pilots and cabin crew.
Ryanair suffered damaging strikes last year after it bowed to pressure in late 2017 to recognise unions for the first 
time. Balpa general secretary Brian Strutton said no progress had been made on issues including pensions, 
maternity benefits and "a fair, transparent, and consistent pay structure". Ryanair, which says it offers some of the 
best conditions for low-cost short-haul Boeing pilots in Europe, did not immediately respond to a request for 
comment.

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives Daily Media Sentiment Rating of -4.00
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Receives Daily Media Sentiment Rating of -4.00
American Banking and Market News
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 589 words
Body
Ryanair logo Headlines about Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been trending extremely negative recently, 
according to InfoTrie Sentiment Analysis. The research group ranks the sentiment of press coverage by monitoring 
more than six thousand news and blog sources in real-time. The firm ranks coverage of public companies on a 
scale of negative five to positive five, with scores closest to five being the most favorable. Ryanair earned a 
coverage optimism score of -4.00 on their scale. InfoTrie also gave news coverage about the transportation 
company an news buzz score of 10 out of 10, indicating that recent press coverage is extremely likely to have an 
effect on the stock's share price in the next several days.  
These are some of the headlines that may have effected Ryanair's ranking: 
•
Ryanair halves 2020 growth plans on Boeing MAX delays - KDAL News  (kdal610.com)
•
Air-freshener firm sues Ryanair over 'use of trademark' - Independent.ie  (independent.ie)
•
News & Tips: Ryanair, Burberry, CRH & more - Investors Chronicle  (investorschronicle.co.uk)
•
Ryanair cuts summer 2020 growth rate on Boeing MAX doubts - CNA  (channelnewsasia.com)
•
What to Watch: Burberry, vote on EU top job, Ryanair reschedule - Yahoo Finance  (finance.yahoo.com)
Shares of RYAAY  opened at $64.62 on Wednesday. The stock's 50-day moving average price is $65.01. Ryanair 
has a one year low of $60.83 and a one year high of $118.76. The company has a current ratio of 0.93, a quick ratio 
of 0.93 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.64. The firm has a market cap of $14.94 billion, a PE ratio of 12.57 and a beta 
of 0.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, May 20th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.74) EPS for the quarter, missing the Zacks' consensus estimate of ($0.64) by ($0.10). 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 20.34% and a net margin of 11.69%. The firm had revenue of $1.45 billion for the 
quarter.  As a group, equities research analysts predict that  Ryanair will post 4.05 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
A number of research analysts have recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. BidaskClub downgraded Zebra 
Technologies from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Tuesday. HSBC  set a  9.00 ($10.47) target price 
on Schaeffler and gave the stock a "buy" rating in a research note on Wednesday, May 22nd. Raymond James  
restated a "hold" rating on shares of PrairieSky Royalty in a research note on Thursday, July 11th. ValuEngine  
upgraded Zynerba Pharmaceuticals from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday, April 1st. 
Finally, JPMorgan Chase & Co.  set a  20.00 ($23.26) target price on STMicroelectronics and gave the stock a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Tuesday, May 21st. Five research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Receives Daily Media Sentiment Rating of -4.00
three have issued  a hold rating and seven have issued  a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock currently 
has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $75.33. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website. 
Further Reading: How Do You Make Money With Penny Stocks? 
Load-Date: July 17, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair cuts flights and weighs closing bases after Boeing 737 Max grounding
Ryanair cuts flights and weighs closing bases after Boeing 737 Max 
grounding
Financial Times (London, England)
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 11
Length: 334 words
Byline: JANINA CONBOYE
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair will cut flights next summer and potentially close some European bases as the result of the 
grounding of the Boeing 737 Max jets after two fatal crashes.
The Irish carrier said the delay to the delivery of new aircraft meant it would receive almost half the number of jets - 
30 compared with 58 - that it was expecting by next May.
The shortfall has led the airline to cut the number of passengers it expects to carry in the year to March 2021 to 
157m, from the 162m previously forecast.
Ryanair said that it would also need to make some cutbacks, including the possible closure of some of its bases for 
summer 2020. Michael O'Leary, chief executive, said the group was starting a series of discussions with its airports 
to determine which of its underperforming or lossmaking bases would take a hit from November this year.
Ryanair said it expected the 737 Max 8, which has been grounded after two crashes in which 346 people died, to 
return to service before the end of this year, although that could be delayed. Boeing hopes to lodge an application 
to regulators to allow the aircraft to fly again by September, with a return to service shortly after. However, Mr 
O'Leary said "it would be prudent to plan for that date to slip by some months, possibly as late as December".
Ryanair cuts flights and weighs closing bases after Boeing 737 Max grounding
Ryanair has ordered 737 Max 200s, a variant of the 737 Max 8 aircraft. With additional seats and an extra 
emergency door, these jets need to be certified by the Federal Aviation Administration in the US and the European 
Aviation Safety Agency.
The airline expected approval for the 737 Max 200s within two months of the Max 737's return to service and hoped 
to receive its first Max 200 aircraft between January and February 2020.
Ryanair can take delivery of only between six and eight new aircraft each month and said that it was therefore 
planning its summer 2020 schedules based on taking 30 deliveries.
Bernstein analysts said the easing of capacity growth was actually a positive for the broader industry.
Load-Date: July 16, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair cuts flights and weighs closing bases after Boeing 737 Max 
grounding

summer 2020. Michael O'Leary, chief executive, said the group was starting a series of discussions with its airports

Load-Date: July 16, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair to curb flights after Boeing 737 Max 8 delay dents aircraft deliveries Airlines
Ryanair to curb flights after Boeing 737 Max 8 delay dents aircraft deliveries; 
Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 17
Length: 495 words
Byline: JANINA CONBOYE
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair will cut flights next summer and potentially close some European bases as a result of the 
grounding of Boeing's 737 Max jets after two fatal crashes.
The Irish carrier said the delay to the delivery of new aircraft would result in it receiving almost half the number of 
jets - 30 compared with 58 - it was expecting by next May.
The shortfall has led the airline to reduce the number of passengers it expects to carry in the year to March 2021 to 
157m, from the 162m previously forecast. The company said it would also need to make some cutbacks, including 
the possible closure of some of its bases for summer 2020.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, said the company was starting a series of discussions with its airports to 
determine which of its underperforming or lossmaking bases would take a hit from November 2019.
Ryanair said it expected the 737 Max 8, which has been grounded after two crashes to return to service before the 
end of 2019 - although that could be delayed.
Boeing hopes to lodge an application to regulators to allow the aircraft to fly again by September, with a return to 
service shortly after. However, Mr O'Leary said "it would be prudent to plan for that date to slip by some months, 
possibly as late as December".
Ryanair to curb flights after Boeing 737 Max 8 delay dents aircraft deliveries Airlines
Ryanair has ordered 737 Max 200s, a variant of the 737 Max 8 aircraft. With additional seats and an extra 
emergency door, these jets need to be certified by the Federal Aviation Administration in the US and the European 
Aviation Safety Agency.
The airline had expected approval for the 737 Max 200s within two months of the Max 737's return to service and 
hoped to receive its first Max 200 between January and February 2020.
Ryanair can only take delivery of between six and eight new aircraft each month and said it was therefore planning 
its summer 2020 schedules based on taking 30 deliveries. Mr O'Leary said that number "could rise, or fall further, 
depending on when the 737 Max actually returns to flight services".
Analysts at Bernstein said the easing of capacity growth was actually a positive for the broader industry and "more 
supportive for European short-haul yields". They said competitors could respond by "electing to ramp up their own 
flying and grab share, or curbing their own capacity growth in an effort to further support yields".
While Ryanair said its cuts to bases or possible closures were linked to the grounding of the 737 Max, Gerald Khoo, 
an analyst at Liberum, said the move "may be interpreted as an indicator of underlying weakness in trading".
Ryanair's share price closed 2.5 per cent up yesterday. Shares in its rivals, including easyJet, Lufthansa and British 
Airways' parent IAG, also rose.
Norwegian Air Shuttle is another European low-cost carrier affected by the grounding of its 737 Max 8 jets. It 
operated 18 Max 8 aircraft out of a total fleet of about 160 planes.
The delay to deliveries means the carrier will receive almost half the number of jets it expected
Load-Date: July 16, 2019
End of Document

forecasts.

run by a new body, said the independent chair of the rail review.

and over, paying an attractive 1.35%.

bomber jackets and bumbags emblazoned with the company’s new logo.

government changed the way in which it calculates compensation for accident victims.

London
Financial Times (London, England)
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 20
Length: 196 words
Body
Aston Martin was in demand after being taken off Jefferies' "sell" list. Earnings forecasts for 2019 still looked too 
high, cash burn remained a problem and launch costs for a sport utility vehicle next year might prompt Aston into 
issuing a convertible bond, said the broker. However, it argued that Aston would look more attractive than peers 
next year as the SUV launch coincided with a strong roster of special editions and a relatively low exposure to 
European carbon emissions legislation.
The wider UK market edged higher as a 27-month low for the pound helped exporters such as Pearson and 
Melrose.
S
Burberry was the FTSE 100's biggest gainer after better than expected sales growth last quarter bolstered hopes of 
a brand revival.
EasyJet led the airlines higher after main rival Ryanair cut its capacity growth targets for summer 2020 to reflect 
Boeing jet delivery delays.
Rightmove slid after a UBS analysis suggested the estate agent website had lost about 1,000 advertisers in 2019.
Investec "buy" advice helped IWG, the owner of Regus office rental. A flotation of WeWork would help crystallise 
the value of IWG's competing Spaces business, Investec said. Bryce Elder

Ryanair warns of summer service cuts, blaming Boeing 737 Max jet grounding
Ryanair warns of summer service cuts, blaming Boeing 737 Max jet 
grounding
City A.M.
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 5
Length: 199 words
Byline: ALEX DANIEL
Body
RYANAIR yesterday warned it had been forced to reschedule its summer 2020 plans due to a delay in the delivery 
of Boeing 737 Max planes.
The budget flyer had ordered 58 Max 200 models from Boeing in time for summer 2020, but now expects just 30 to 
be ready by then.
That will more than halve Ryanair's growth rate next summer, from an expected seven per cent to just three per 
cent. Passenger numbers will also fall from 162m to 157m for the year to March 2021.
As a result, Ryanair warned it will have to make "some base cuts and closures", not only for summer 2020 but also 
for winter this year.
"We are starting a series of discussions with our airports to determine which of Ryanair's underperforming or loss-
making bases should suffer these short-term cuts and/or closures from November 2019," boss Michael O'Leary 
warned.
The 737 Max 200s Ryanair has ordered are a variant of the 737 Max aircraft the US banned from skies following 
two fatal crashes linked to issues with the model's anti-stall software. These models may not return to service until 
December.
www.Markets.com analyst Neil Wilson said: "It's not all bad - stripping out excess capacity should boost pricing 
power and lift margins."
Ryanair warns of summer service cuts, blaming Boeing 737 Max jet grounding
Load-Date: July 17, 2019
End of Document
Burberry leads FTSE 100 higher on weak pound LONDON REPORT
Burberry leads FTSE 100 higher on weak pound; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
July 17, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 15
Length: 162 words
Body
LONDON's main index rose yesterday as Burberry scaled an 11-month high after its firstquarter update showed 
new designs boosted sales, and a weaker sterling aided exporter stocks.
The FTSE 100 added 0.6 per cent to 7,77.20 points, its best day in nearly two weeks, outperforming the broader 
European markets.
Gains in Easyjet and Aston Martin helped the FTSE 250 advance 0.4 per cent to 19,656.05 [points, despite a hit to 
the local currency from mounting Brexit jitters.
Luxury brand Burberry jumped more than 15 per cent on its best day ever, after it posted a stronger-than-expected 
rise in first-quarter comparable-store sales and affirmed its annual forecast.
Airline stocks climbed after Ryanair said deliveries of Boeing's 737 Max planes may be delayed further, raising the 
prospects of easing over-capacity in the European market.
Shares in Ryanair, which cut its forecast for growth in traveller numbers next summer, and British Airways owner 
IAG gained 2.6 per cent each.
Load-Date: July 17, 2019
End of Document
Boeing jet trouble leads to cuts at Europe's busiest airline
Boeing jet trouble leads to cuts at Europe's busiest airline
Associated Press Financial Wire
July 16, 2019 Tuesday 2:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 409 words
Byline: By GREGORY KATZ, Associated Press
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) - Europe's biggest airline, budget carrier Ryanair, will cut flights and close some of its bases 
beginning this winter because of the delay to deliveries of the Boeing 737 Max plane, which has been grounded 
globally after two fatal crashes.
The airline also warned Tuesday that its growth in European summer traffic for 2020 will be lower than expected 
because of the slowed deliveries.
Ryanair chief Michael O'Leary said the airline "remains committed" to the Boeing 737 Max and expects it to be back 
in service before the end of the year but that the date is uncertain.
Ryanair, which is Europe's top airline by passengers, says some delays are expected and doubts about when the 
plane can return to the skies means it will take delivery of only 30 Max jets a year from now, rather than the 
previously scheduled 58.
He says the airline will close some of its bases as a result with a hope to return to "normal" growth levels in 2021. 
No details about the planned base cuts were provided.
Analysts at market research firm FXPro note that while Europe's economy is slowing, there is no lack of demand for 
flying, so Ryanair's decision could cause flight tickets to rise somewhat.
Boeing's 737 Max has been grounded after the Lion Air crash off the coast of Indonesia in October and the 
Ethiopian Airlines crash in March that killed a total of 346 people.
Preliminary reports indicate that flight-control software called MCAS pushed the nose of the plane down in both 
crashes. Chicago-based Boeing did not tell pilots about MCAS until after the first crash. The company is working on 
changes to make the software more reliable and easier to control.
Concerns about viability of the new aircraft remains, however.
Boeing jet trouble leads to cuts at Europe's busiest airline
The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration is due to review Boeing's fixes and has said it is following a thorough 
process, but has no timetable for when the recertification will be completed. European regulators have to then also 
approve the jets before they can be used in the region.
American Airlines said this week that it will keep the Boeing 737 Max plane off its schedule until Nov. 3, which is 
two months longer than it had planned. That will result in the cancellation of about 115 flights per day.
United Airlines has also extended its cancellations until Nov. 3. The company has 14 Max jets while American has 
24 of them. Southwest Airlines, which has 34 Max jets - more than any other carrier - is canceling about 150 flights 
per day.
Load-Date: July 17, 2019
End of Document
Wall Street Steady Pre-Bell; Futures Flat, Europe Higher, Asia Up
Wall Street Steady Pre-Bell; Futures Flat, Europe Higher, Asia Up
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
July 16, 2019 Tuesday 7:21 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 634 words
Body
 Wall Street pre-bell Tuesday is steady, with US stock market index futures pointing to an opening bell largely 
unchanged from Monday's close. European bourses are trading higher although Frankfurt is flat, and Asian 
exchanges closed mixed but mostly higher ahead of earnings season. The US Senate starts two days of hearings 
on Facebook's (FB) cryptocurrency Libra. Ryanair, the European discount airline, cut its growth forecast due to the 
grounding Boeing's (BA) 737 Max jet. Bitcoin trades at $19,716, oil trades for $59.70, and 10-year US Treasuries 
offer 2.09%.
On the economic calendar at 8:30 am ET are retail sales and import and export prices, followed at 9:15 by the 
industrial production release. The National Association of Home Builders Housing Market Index and business 
inventories are at 10 am. 
For Federal Reserve-watchers, Governor Michelle Bowman and Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic speak at 
8:15 am, and Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan speaks at 12:20 pm. 
In the futures, the S&P 500 is up 0.03%, the Nasdaq is up 0.04% and the Dow Jones is off 0.01%
In Europe, the British FTSE 100 is up 0.30%, the French CAC is up 0.18%  and the German DAX is off 0.02%.
Asian stock markets generally gained Tuesday, as traders awaited pending US retail-sales data and cues from the 
unfolding earnings season. Upside sentiment was capped by the China-US trade dispute, as well as the Tokyo-
Seoul trade dispute over WWII reparations, said analysts. Hong Kong gained ground, although Shanghai edged 
lower and Tokyo lost ground on a stronger yen. Other regional exchanges mostly finished in the green.
In Japan, the Nikkei 225 opened lower after a three-day weekend and declined in trading, finishing down 0.69% as 
a stronger yen undercut export-oriented issues. The yen traded under 108 to the US dollar, compared with nearly 
113 to the greenback in April. 
The benchmark Nikkei 225 fell 150.65 to 21,535.25, as losing issues outnumbered gainers 160 to 57.
Wall Street Steady Pre-Bell; Futures Flat, Europe Higher, Asia Up
On the upside on a down day was cable manufacturer Oki Electric Industry (OKIEF, 6703:Tokyo), up 4.5%, 
followed by brewer Sapporo (SOOBF, 2501:Tokyo ), up 3.4%, and entertainment company Toho (9602:Tokyo), up 
2.8%.
On the downside were Casio Computer (CSIOY, 6952:Tokyo), off 4.0%, and oil industry engineers JGC Corp. 
(JGCCY, 1963:Tokyo), losing 3.2%.
In economic news, the Bank of Japan will back a government deficit-spending program slated for October, when the 
national sales tax is set to rise to 10% from 8%, a former central bank official told Bloomberg. The central bank 
would like to show it is working with the government to support the economy, said Hideo Hayakawa, former 
executive director at the Bank of Japan. 
The broad gauge Hong Kong Hang Seng Index opened evenly, slumped then recovered to finish up 64.74, or 
0.23%, to 28.619,62, as gaining issues outnumbered losers 32 to 16.
Leading the upside were Macau gaming houses Galaxy Entertainment (27:HK) and Sands China (1928:HK), up 
2.9% and 2.4% respectively, and knitwear-maker Shenzhou International (2313:HK) gained 2.8%.
On the downside were China Overseas Land (688:HK), off 1.2%, and China Mengniu Dairy (2319:HK), off 0.9%.
On the mainland, the Shanghai Composite fell 0.16% to 2,937.62.
In other developments, Hong Kong media leader Jimmy Lai said US President Donald Trump is wise to "play 
hardball" with China's ruling communists on trade because "that's the only thing they understand," the Wall Street 
Journal reported. But Lai urged the US to "show humility" and allow China to save face in striking a new deal.
On the other exchanges, the S. Korean Kospi inclined 0.45%; the Taiwan TWSE edged up 0.09%; the Australian 
ASX 200 fell 0.18%; the Singapore Straits Times Index rose 0.36%, and the Thai Set declined 0.21%. In late trading 
in Mumbai, the Sensex was up 0.60%.

Ryanair Cuts Summer 2020 Growth Rate More Than Half, Now Expects 737 MAX Flight Services in December
Ryanair Cuts Summer 2020 Growth Rate More Than Half, Now Expects 737 
MAX Flight Services in December
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
July 16, 2019 Tuesday 5:06 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 362 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY, RYA.L), Europe's largest budget airline, said early Tuesday that its summer 2020 growth rate 
would be cut by more than half and winter 2019 schedules won't remain unaffected because of the delay in Boeing 
(BA) 737 MAX aircraft deliveries, which may not return to skies until December. 
The group said in a statement early on Tuesday that it was now planning the summer 2020 schedules with just over 
half the original number of 737s penciled in for delivery next year. 
The 737 was involved in two crashes earlier this year, in Indonesia and Ethiopia, in which hundreds of people were 
killed. Boeing, which identified a software failure as a common contributory factor to both the fatal accidents, 
recently announced a $100 million program to support the families of the victims. 
"Boeing is hoping that a certification package will be submitted to regulators by September with a return to service 
shortly thereafter," the European carrier said in a statement. "It would be prudent to plan for that date to slip by 
some months, possibly as late as December."
As Ryanair has ordered the Boeing MAX200s, which are a variant of the MAX aircraft, these need to be separately 
certified by aviation authorities. Ryanair expects that the MAX200 will be approved for flight services within two 
months of the MAX returning to service.
Accordingly, Ryanair now hopes to receive its first MAX200 aircraft sometime between January and February. 
Since Ryanair can only take delivery of between six to eight new aircraft each month, it is planning the summer 
2020 schedules based on taking up to 30 B737 MAX aircraft deliveries up to end of May 2020. This is fewer than 
the 58 MAX aircraft Boeing originally scheduled for the summer of next year.
"This will cut Ryanair's summer 2020 growth rate from 7% to 3% and means full-year traffic growth for the year to 
March 2021 will be cut from 162 million guests to approximately 157 million," the company said in a statement. 
Ryanair Cuts Summer 2020 Growth Rate More Than Half, Now Expects 737 MAX Flight Services in December
"This shortfall in aircraft deliveries will necessitate some base cuts and closures for Summer 2020, but also for the 
Winter 2019 schedule," the company said.
Price: 63.77, Change: +0.12, Percent Change: +0.19

LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Capacity Growth Hit by Grounded Boeing Jet
LONDON BRIEFING: Ryanair Capacity Growth Hit by Grounded Boeing Jet
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
July 16, 2019 Tuesday 3:02 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 359 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings on Tuesday said it expects Boeing 737 MAX aircraft delivery delays to slow its capacity growth. 
The stock was down 0.9% at the London open.
Ryanair said it remains committed to the B737 MAX aircraft. It expects the troubled jet - grounded globally by 
regulators after two fatal crashes - to return to flying service before the end of 2019, but the exact date of this return 
remains uncertain.
The Irish budget airline is to revise its summer 2020 schedule due to the 737 delivery delays.
As a result, Ryanair said it expects summer 2020 traffic growth rate to slow to 3% from 7%, which means traffic 
growth for its full financial year to March 2021 will be cut to around 157 million passenger from 162 million.
"This shortfall in aircraft deliveries will necessitate some base cuts and closures for summer 2020, but also for the 
winter 2019 schedule. We are starting a series of discussions with our airports to determine which of Ryanair's 
underperforming or loss making bases should suffer these short term cuts and/or closures from November 2019. 
We will also be consulting with our people and our unions in planning and implementing these base cuts and 
closures, which are directly caused by the B737 MAX delivery delays to the B737 MAX program," said Chief 
Executive Officer Michael O'Leary.

USD1.1254 (USD1.1258)
