France 's plan to levy tax on flights hits European airlines' share prices
France's plan to levy tax on flights hits European airlines' share prices
City A.M.
July 10, 2019 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 173 words
Byline: MARINE PENNETIER
Body
3.04% FRANCE will introduce a tax on airlines flying from its airports to help support the environment, its transport 
minister said yesterday, in a move expected to raise around (EURO)180m (£159.4m) from 2020.
2.00% Shares in airlines across Europe fell on the news, with Air France and Easyjet down just over three per cent, 
Lufthansa down two per cent and Ryanair down almost five per cent yesterday.
The tax will be (EURO)1.50 for flights within France or the European Union, (EURO)3 for economy flights out of the 
EU, (EURO)9 for intra-EU business class and up to (EURO)18 for business class tickets out of the EU. Transit 
flights will not be taxed.
Transport minister Elisabeth Borne said proceeds would be used to finance daily transport in France, notably local 
trains.
Air France said the tax would significantly hurt its competitiveness and represent an additional cost of more than 
(EURO)60m per year.
The French government also said that from 2020 it expected to raise (EURO)140m from reducing tax benefits on 
diesel for trucks.
Reuters
Load-Date: July 10, 2019
France 's plan to levy tax on flights hits European airlines' share prices
End of Document
France to slap new 'ecotax' on plane tickets from 2020
France to slap new 'ecotax' on plane tickets from 2020
Associated Press Financial Wire
July 9, 2019 Tuesday 5:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 511 words
Byline: By THOMAS ADAMSON and FRANK JORDANS, Associated Press
Dateline: PARIS 
Body
PARIS (AP) - France will introduce a new charge on plane tickets from next year, with revenue used to fund 
environment-friendly alternatives, the country's transport minister said Tuesday.
The "ecotax" costing between 1.50 euros ($1.7) and 18 euros ($20) will apply to most flights departing in France, 
Elisabeth Borne said.
The only exceptions will be for domestic flights to Corsica and France's overseas territories, and connecting flights 
that pass through France. It will not apply to flights arriving in France.
Shares in Air France/KLM and budget airlines EasyJet and Ryanair dropped following the announcement.
Industry group IATA, which favors a system that allows airlines to offset their emissions by paying for carbon 
reduction efforts elsewhere, called the French ticket charge "misguided."
"National taxes will do nothing to assist the aviation industry in its sustainability efforts," IATA spokesman Anthony 
Concil said, warning that instead of helping airlines invest in cleaner fuels and technology it could end up harming 
the French aviation industry and jeopardize jobs.
But the move received a cautious welcome from environmental campaigners, who argue that the airline industry 
needs to curb its greenhouse gas emissions as part of wider efforts to combat climate change.
"This alone won't do much, but it's at least a recognition by the French government that more is required," said 
Andrew Murphy, an air travel expert at Brussels-based group Transport and Environment.
According to Borne, domestic and European flights will be taxed at 1.50 euros for economy tickets and 9 euros 
($10) for business class, rising to 18 euros for business flights outside the EU.
By comparison, Britain's air passenger duty for standard passenger planes starts at 13 pounds ($16.20), rising to a 
maximum of 172 pounds ($214.20), and generates more than 3 billion pounds in Treasury revenue every year.
France to slap new 'ecotax' on plane tickets from 2020
The French tax is expected to raise over 180 million euros ($200 million) from 2020 to invest in eco-friendly 
transport infrastructure, including rail. It comes on top of a similar ticket charge introduced over a decade ago by 
former French President Jacques Chirac, the proceeds of which go toward medical aid for poor countries.
Murphy said the French move could boost efforts to introduce a Europe-wide tax on aviation to reflect plane travel's 
environmental impact.
Germany, Italy and some Nordics nations also have ticket taxes. Several European countries are meanwhile 
pushing for the VAT exemption that airline fuel enjoys in Europe to be dropped.
Germany's Environment Ministry said Tuesday it supports discussions on additional CO2-based pricing systems for 
air travel to reduce the industry's contribution to man-made greenhouse gas emissions, currently estimated at more 
than 2% but forecast to grow significantly in coming decades.
"What's more, the conditions for competition between air, road and rail travel need to be made fairer," the ministry 
said in a statement. "This is something we in Europe need to achieve together."
___
Jordans contributed from Berlin.
Load-Date: July 10, 2019
End of Document
European ADRs Move Lower in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 9, 2019 Tuesday 10:39 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Body
 American Depositary Receipts of European stocks were trading 0.70% lower at 1,055.00 on the BNY Mellon 
Europe Select ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, gainers were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and hotel 
booking website Trivago (TRVG), which climbed 8.3% and 4.7% respectively. They were followed by 3D printer 
maker Voxeljet (VJET) and internet advertising firm Criteo (CRTO), which were up a respective 2% and 1.7%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by semiconductor company Sequans Communications (SQNS) and 
kidney dialysis company Fresenius Medical Care (FMS), which fell 7.6% and 4.3%, respectively. Computer 
hardware company Logitech (LOGI) and Deutsche Bank (DB) dropped a respective 2.8% and 2.6%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biotech firm Autolus Therapeutics (AUTL) and Trinity Biotech (TRIB), 
which rose 4.7% and 4.5%, respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals 
(GWPH), which gained 1.9%, and pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), advancing 0.9%.
Decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical firm Amarin (AMRN) and tobacco and consumer 
goods company British American Tobacco (BTI), which fell 4.8% and 2%, respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical company Verona Pharma (VRNA) and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which lost a respective 
1.9% and 1.8%.

Ryanair announces new Bristol ski route to Grenoble
Ryanair announces new Bristol ski route to Grenoble
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
July 4, 2019 Thursday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 276 words
Highlight: Ryanair has announced a new weekly Bristol ski route to/from Grenoble commencing in January 2020, 
as part of Ryanairs extended Bristol Winter 19 schedule.
Body
Bristol consumers and visitors can now book their ski holidays to Grenoble as far out as March 2020, enjoying even 
lower fares and Ryanair's customer care improvements, including: Lowest Fares - find a cheaper fare within 3 
hours, get paid the difference plus (EURO)/£ 5 MyRyanair creditPunctuality - deliver 90% target (excl. ATC) or 5% 
off following month's air faresCustomer Care Charter - EU261 claims processed in 10 days, new 24/7 support, 
connect in 2 minsCare Improvements - 48-hour free of charge grace period for changes to bookingsEnvironmental 
Improvements - carbon offset programme, environmental partnerships & plastic free in 5 yearsNew Ryanair Choice 
- £199 annual fee for free seats, fast-track & priority boarding for freq. guestsDigital Improvements - new fare finder, 
sports tickets, bespoke travel guides & faster mobileTo celebrate its new Bristol route, Ryanair has launched a seat 
sale with fares starting from £19.99 for travel in October, which must be booked by midnight Saturday (6 Jul), only 
on the Ryanair.com website. 
Ryanair's Eimear Ryan said: "Ryanair is pleased to announce a new Bristol route to Grenoble commencing in 
January 2020, which will operate weekly as part of our extended Bristol Winter 2019 schedule. Customers can now 
book their trip to Grenoble as far out as March 2020, getting to the slopes on the lowest fares this winter.  To 
celebrate, we are releasing seats for sale from Bristol from just £19.99 for travel until October 2019 which are 
available for booking until midnight Saturday (6 July). These seats are sure to sell quickly so customers should log 
on to Ryanair.com today to avoid missing out."
Load-Date: July 11, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair Releases June CO2 Emissions Statistics
Ryanair Releases June CO2 Emissions Statistics
RTT News (United States)
July 4, 2019 Thursday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 81 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Irish low-cost airline Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) said that its CO2 per passenger/km for June 2019 was 66g, 
almost half the rate of other flag carrier European airlines. 
 Ryanair also published environmental taxes to dispel the myth that airlines pay no environmental taxes. Ryanair 
paid over 540 million euros in environment taxes in 2018 and will pay over 630 million euros in 2019, up 17%. This 
equates to 4.12 euros per passenger, which is 11% of Ryanair's average air fare.        
Load-Date: July 4, 2019
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Wednesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 3, 2019 Wednesday 10:41 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 229 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.01% higher at 1,072.53 on the BNY Mellon 
Europe Select ADR Index on Wednesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by medical equipment company Edap (EDAP) and biopharmaceutical 
firm DBV Technologies (DBVT), which rose 4.5% each. They were followed by brewing company AB InBev (BUD) 
and biopharmaceutical company Biofrontera (BFRA), which were up 2.8% and 2.1% respectively. 
The decliners in continental Europe were led by pharmaceutical company Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), which 
tumbled 11.8%, followed by Italian furniture maker Natuzzi (NTZ) and oil and gas company TOTAL (TOT), which 
were down 1.2% each. Automation company ABB (ABB) was off 0.7%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Amarin (AMRN) and 
telecommunications operator Vodafone Group (VOD), which rose 5.7% and 2.5% respectively. They were followed 
by tobacco and consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI) and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), 
which were up 1.8% each.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by Trinity Biotech (TRIB), which fell 4%, followed by 
biopharmaceutical companies Akari Therapeutics (AKTX) and Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which lost 2.5% 
and 1.8% respectively. Oil and gas company BP (BP) was off 1.2%.
Price: 23.30, Change: +0.93, Percent Change: +4.16
Load-Date: July 4, 2019
End of Document

FTSE 100 Edges Higher In Cautious Trade
FTSE 100 Edges Higher In Cautious Trade
RTT News (United States)
July 2, 2019 Tuesday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 358 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       U.K. stocks shrugged off weak regional leads to edge higher on Tuesday, with financials and energy stocks 
leading the surge. 
 The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 37 points or 0.50 percent at 7,535 in opening deals after rallying around 1 
percent on Monday. 
 Elsewhere, major markets in Germany and France were subdued after U.S. President Donald Trump said on 
Monday that any trade deal with China would need to be somewhat tilted in favor of the United States, raising 
doubts over the U.S-China trade truce.
 Also, the United States has intensified its fight with the European Union over aircraft subsidies, proposing tariffs on 
$4 billion of additional EU goods.
 Asia-focused lender HSBC Holdings rose 0.8 percent, Standard Chartered gained 0.7 percent and Prudential 
added 0.8 percent. 
 BP Plc rose about 1 percent and Royal Dutch Shell gained half a percent after OPEC agreed to extend oil supply 
cuts until March 2020.
 Advertising giant WPP fell over 2 percent. The company confirmed that it has entered into exclusive discussions to 
sell a majority shareholding in Kantar to Bain Capital for a headline enterprise value of about $4 billion.
 Irish low-cost airline Ryanair Holdings advanced 0.6 percent after reporting growth in passenger traffic figures for 
June. 
 Hill & Smith Holdings gained 1 percent after it appointed Hannah Nichols as Chief Financial Officer and a member 
of the Board.
FTSE 100 Edges Higher In Cautious Trade
 Jupiter Fund Management slumped 6.7 percent after the company said it is considering naming Devon Equity as 
an adviser for its European Opportunities Trust. 
 In economic releases, U.K. house prices increased at a slightly slower pace in June, data from Nationwide Building 
Society showed.
 House prices rose 0.5 percent year-on-year in June, following a 0.6 percent increase in May. Nonetheless, this was 
faster than the expected 0.2 percent rise.
 The U.K. construction sector contracted the most in more than a decade in June, survey data from IHS Markit 
revealed. 
 The IHS Markit/Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply Purchasing Managers' Index fell unexpectedly to 43.1 
in June from 48.6 in May. The reading was forecast to rise to 49.2.        
Load-Date: July 2, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Traffic Rises 13% in June
Ryanair Traffic Rises 13% in June
MT Newswires Live Briefs
July 2, 2019 Tuesday 6:43 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 79 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) said pre-market Tuesday that traffic in June rose 13% to 14.2 million passengers from 
the prior year.
The Irish-based budget carrier said load factor, or the percentage of seats filled with passengers, was 97% 
compared with 96% a year ago. Meanwhile, traffic at its Laudamotion subsidiary was 600,000 customers with a 
96% load factor.
The company said it operated nearly 78,00 scheduled flights in June.
Price: 65.26, Change: +1.12, Percent Change: +1.75
Load-Date: July 3, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair June Traffic Up 13%
Ryanair June Traffic Up 13%
RTT News (United States)
July 2, 2019 Tuesday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 100 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Irish low-cost airline Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) reported that its traffic in the month of June 2019 increased 13 
percent to 14.2 million passengers from last year's 12.6 million passengers.
 Ryanair alone recorded 13.6 million customers, up 8 percent from last year. Lauda carried 0.6 million passengers 
in the month.
 Total load factor was 97 percent.
 Ryanair said it operated almost 78,000 scheduled flights in June.
 For the rolling annual period, Ryanair reported passenger traffic of 146.5 million, an increase of 10 percent over 
prior year. Load factor was 96 percent for the period.        
Load-Date: July 2, 2019

'Drunk' Airline Passenger Arrested For Allegedly Trying To Punch Female Airport Official
'Drunk' Airline Passenger Arrested For Allegedly Trying To Punch Female 
Airport Official
International Business Times News
July 1, 2019 Monday 8:46 AM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 384 words
Body
Jul 01, 2019( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  A passenger on 
board a Ryanair flight was arrested on suspicion of being drunk and disorderly. Authorities said that a group of 
passengers heading to a beach music festival in Croatia on Saturdayturned "rowdy" before takeoff from 
theManchester Airport inEngland.Police were called when trouble erupted, causing a two-hour delay to 
flightFR9501 to Zadar. 
Authorities said one of the passengersallegedly tried to punch a female official at the boarding gate, Manchester 
Evening News reported. The passenger who was arrested was not named.Other officials intervened and the 
passenger was told he would not be allowed to fly. The rest of the group was also warned. The drama led to a delay 
for those heading to Hideout Festival at Zrće beach in Croatia.An eyewitness said some of the passengers had 
gone through the gate and then were told to return to the terminal before boarding."The gate agents of this flight 
from Manchester to Zadar (June 29) requested police assistance ahead of take off after a small number of 
passengers became disruptive, and one passenger was denied boarding," Ryanair said in a statement, according 
to U.K.'s Mirror Online.[1] "The safety and comfort of our customers, crew and aircraft is our number one priority. 
The flight departed to Zadar following a short delay."A spokeswoman for Greater Manchester Police confirmed 
officers were called to the gate at T3 to arrest a 43-year-old man. In this representational photo, a Ryanair Boeing 
737-800 aircraft lands at Barcelona's 'El Prat' airport, Sept. 28, 2018. Photo: Pau Barrena/AFP/Getty Images In 
February, an EasyJet passenger got drunk[2] on a flight from Gibraltar to Manchesterand abused the cabin crew as 
well as his co-passengers. Last month, the man appeared in court and was not given any jail time.Authorities said 
thatPhilip Carolan, 43, was accused of drinking duty-free liquor that he claimed he had bought atthe Rock of 
Gibraltar. Authorities said Carolan was found with four liters of vodka in his possession. [ 1]:

Ryanair 's Q1 profit drops 21%
Ryanair's Q1 profit drops 21%
AirFinance Journal
July 2019
Copyright 2019 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 262 words
Byline: Oliver Clark
Body
Ryanair has blamed higher fuel costs, downward pressure on fares and the integration of Lauda for a 21% fall in its 
first-quarter profit.
The low-cost carrier says post-tax profits fell to (EURO)243 million ($270 million) in the period to 30 June from 
(EURO)309 million in the same quarter in 2018.
Revenues grew 11% to (EURO)2.31 billion from (EURO)2.08 billion.
Costs rose 19% to (EURO)2.04 billion from (EURO)1.71 billion. Ryanair says its fuel bill rose 24% to (EURO)784 
million from (EURO)631 million while integrating its Austrian subsidiary also pushed up its costs.
Gross cash increased by (EURO)921 million to (EURO)4.12 billion, while gross debt rose by (EURO)891 million to 
(EURO)4.54 billion due to a new (EURO)750 million "low-cost" syndicated bank facility and the (EURO)223 million 
impact of IFRS 16 accounting. The airline made (EURO)80 million of debt repayments during the period.
Cash and cash equivalents stood at (EURO)2.02 billion at end of the quarter, from (EURO)1.35 billion in the same 
quarter a year before.
The Irish carrier says that delivery of its first five Boeing 737 Max aircraft has been delayed until January 2020 "at 
the earliest". Ryanair now estimates it will only receive 30 Max aircraft by the summer of 2020, from the 58 it 
previously expected.
Aircraft rental payments fell by 18% to (EURO)14.7 million as a result of six leased 737s being phased out during 
the period and the effects of changes to its accounting methods.
 The airline is guiding for a "flat" full-year post tax profit in a range of (EURO)750 million to (EURO)950 million.
Load-Date: August 19, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa profit falls in Q2
Lufthansa profit falls in Q2
AirFinance Journal
July 2019
Copyright 2019 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 368 words
Byline: Oliver Clark
Body
Lufthansa Group's operating profit fell 25% in the second quarter on the back of rising fuel prices, pressure on 
yields and competition in its European markets.
The Star Alliance group made an operating profit of (EURO)754 million ($840 million), down from (EURO)1 billion in 
the same quarter last year.
Group revenues rose by 4% to (EURO)9.6 billion, from (EURO)9.3 billion, while operating costs rose 7% to 
(EURO)9.5 billion.
Profits across the group's network carriers, which includes Austrian, Lufthansa mainline and Swiss, fell 16% to 
(EURO)725 million from (EURO)861 million. The Star Alliance says that "substantial" fuel price rises incurred by the 
carriers could not be passed on to customers.
Eurowings' losses doubled to (EURO)16 million from (EURO)8 million, with the German airline group warning the 
budget carrier's profits are under "significant pressure".
The group's cargo division incurred a (EURO)9 million loss, while at MRO arm Lufthansa Technik operating profit 
fell to (EURO)118 million from (EURO)120 million.
"Our earnings are feeling the effects of tough competition in Europe and sizeable overcapacities, especially on our 
short-haul routes out of Germany and Austria," said Lufthansa chief financial officer Ulrik Svensson.
"We are responding to this by further reducing our costs and increasing our flexibility. And with the turnaround plan 
which we recently presented, we also intend to make Eurowings a sustainably profitable airline."
The group experienced a "solid performance" on Asian routes, while its Middle East and African operational 
performance "improves". Its services to South America continue to cause a "drag".
Speaking on an analysts call today, Svensson says the group's free cash flow position declined to a "negative 
number" during the quarter.
Svensson says yields in Europe, particularly Germany and Austria, remain "under pressure" because of market-
wide overcapacity, "aggressive competition" and increasingly price-sensitive demand.
Lufthansa profit falls in Q2
He expects Lufthansa's European carriers to remain locked in a "very tough price" competition with Ryanair and 
EasyJet this year and in 2020.
Svensson adds that the Lufthansa Group expects to complete the sale of LSG Europe this year.  
Load-Date: August 19, 2019

Icelandic-Irish team plan Wow Air successor
Icelandic-Irish team plan Wow Air successor
AirFinance Journal
July 2019
Copyright 2019 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 140 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Two former executives of Wow Air are planning to resurrect the Icelandic carrier under the provisional name of 
WAB Air.
Arnar Magnusson and Svein Steinporsson plan to hold 25% of WAB (We Are Back) through their company Neo, 
while 75% will be owned by Avianta Capital, an Irish investment fund owned by Aislinn Whittley-Ryan, part of the 
family that founded Ryanair.
Avianta aims to commit ISK5 billion ($39.2m) for its stake, reports Icelandic business publication Marka&urinn, with 
$30 million of that funding to be sourced from Icelandic banks Arion Bank and Landsbankinn under one-year loans.
Plans are for WAB Air to start flights as soon as this autumn and then expand within a year to six aircraft serving 14 
destinations in Europe and the US.
Wow Air's former chief executive officer, Skuli Morgensen, is not involved in the new venture.
Load-Date: July 29, 2019
End of Document

The wandering rocks Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences lightly in the tale of two washed-up 
Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain . By Jon D....
The wandering rocks; Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences 
lightly in the tale of two washed-up Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain. 
By Jon Day
Financial Times (London, England)
June 29, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LIFE AND ARTS;BUSINESS; Pg. 10
Length: 841 words
Body
K evin Barry's first novel, City of Bohane, was a cinematic gangster noir set in a fictional city in the west of Ireland in 
a dystopian, technology-free future. It was a swaggering, dazzling book, studded with a kind of Hibernian version of 
A Clockwork Orange's nadsat, and it won Barry the IMPAC prize for fiction in 2013.
His second, Beatlebone, for which he won the Goldsmiths Prize in 2015, was a quieter affair, though no less 
satisfying for that. A formally inventive quest narrative, it followed John Lennon as he travelled to Dorinish, the small 
island in County Mayo he bought in 1967, where he hoped to escape from the world for a few days and indulge in 
some primal scream therapy. Barry seems always to have been interested in the tension between the smallness of 
Ireland - the "little kingdom" that Lennon describes in Beatlebone (a phrase also used in the title of Barry's first 
short-story collection) - and the expansiveness of its writing, and this tension is one that animates his third novel.
Night Boat to Tangier feels like something of a fusion of his previous books. It opens as two "fading Irish gangsters" 
- Maurice "Moss" Hearne and Charlie Redman - sit in a ferry terminal in the southern Spanish port of Algeciras. The 
terminal, a non-place through which walk-on characters can drift, makes a good stage set, and it's hard to avoid 
comparisons with Beckett. Like Vladimir and Estragon, Moss and Charlie are waiting. They're waiting for Moss's 
estranged daughter Dilly to pass through on her way to or from Tangier, but they're also waiting for death.
As night falls they harangue dreadlocked travellers who they think might know Dilly, and reminisce about their lives 
of drug smuggling, dodgy real estate speculation, low-level violence and lost love. Some chapters are set in the 
The wandering rocks Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences lightly in the tale of two washed-up 
Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain . By Jon D....
past, in Ireland, London and other parts of Ryanair-accessible Europe, and describe Moss's relationship with Dilly's 
mother Cynthia, and his affairs. But most of the narrative is confined to the terminal, and the question of whether 
Dilly will ever arrive.
The partners' glory days are very much behind them. Cannabis is no longer smuggled: it's grown hydroponically in 
bedsits. The protection racket is not what it was. "The years have turned and left Maurice and Charlie behind", 
writes Barry, "the men are elegiacal, woeful, heavy in the bones. Also they are broke and grieving."
If the set-up evokes Beckett the dramatist, the language of Night Boat to Tangier is much more like that of Beckett 
the novelist. It is written in a kind of ornate pub-lyricism that casts into relief the grime and squalor of its subjects: a 
baroque High Style fused with low-life garrulousness that reminded me of the Beckett of Murphy, and of the trilogy. 
Descriptions are dense and evocative. Charlie's face "somehow has an antique look, like a court player's, medieval, 
a man who'd strum his lute for you"; Moss's "left eye is smeared and dead"; a landlord has "a papery film like 
mothskin stretched over his eyes"; the sea "guffs up a newsy froth" while a trawler, "flush with octopus", "waddles 
into port" and an SUV stops to "disgorge a unit of fat kids". The Beckettian influence is there, more explicitly, when 
Moss, exiled to London, sees, as Murphy did before him, "the lights of all the cages" of the city's lonely tenements 
go on, near the "great maw of Finsbury Park".
This is rich fare, and Barry's strident image-making can threaten to take over at times. Why need a payphone be a 
"coin phone"? Are a line of larches really "primly erect, arrogant as surgeons"? "Watch out for words most of all", 
Dilly thinks, knowingly enacting her own fears, at one point. "Watch out for ripe language - it means your words may 
be about to go off." Beckett eventually shied away from this kind of writing, as though wary of his innate fluency, 
and tried to rid his prose of its colour by composing in French before translating himself into English, but it is 
testament to Barry's ear that he is fully aware of the threat, and to his skill that his prose never reaches its sell-by 
date.
Like Murphy, Night Boat to Tangier is really about exile and loss, and about the way in which Ireland often seems 
unable to fully sustain and nourish its young. In the late 1990s, buoyed up by Celtic Tiger optimism, Cynthia and 
Moss invest his money in a swish housing development in the countryside (the builders are nervous about the 
proximity of a fairy fort, and the project founders). Later Red and Moss run away to the continent to seek their 
fortune. But abroad they only find disappointment.
For James Joyce's Stephen Dedalus, Ireland was the "sow that eats her farrow". For Moss and Charlie it is, with its 
"smiling friends" and "speaking rocks" and "sea memory", a haunted, claustrophobic place: a "wet tormented rock 
on the edge of the black Atlantic". But it is also a place that it is difficult to escape the influence of.
Jon Day is the author of 'Homing' ( John Murray) Ni ht B t t T i Night Boat to Tangier by Kevin Barry Canongate

The wandering rocks Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences lightly in the tale of two washed-up 
Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain . By Jon D....
The wandering rocks; Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences 
lightly in the tale of two washed-up Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain. 
By Jon Day
Financial Times (London, England)
June 29, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LIFE AND ARTS;BUSINESS; Pg. 10
Length: 841 words
Body
K evin Barry's first novel, City of Bohane, was a cinematic gangster noir set in a fictional city in the west of Ireland in 
a dystopian, technology-free future. It was a swaggering, dazzling book, studded with a kind of Hibernian version of 
A Clockwork Orange's nadsat, and it won Barry the IMPAC prize for fiction in 2013.
His second, Beatlebone, for which he won the Goldsmiths Prize in 2015, was a quieter affair, though no less 
satisfying for that. A formally inventive quest narrative, it followed John Lennon as he travelled to Dorinish, the small 
island in County Mayo he bought in 1967, where he hoped to escape from the world for a few days and indulge in 
some primal scream therapy. Barry seems always to have been interested in the tension between the smallness of 
Ireland - the "little kingdom" that Lennon describes in Beatlebone (a phrase also used in the title of Barry's first 
short-story collection) - and the expansiveness of its writing, and this tension is one that animates his third novel.
Night Boat to Tangier feels like something of a fusion of his previous books. It opens as two "fading Irish gangsters" 
- Maurice "Moss" Hearne and Charlie Redman - sit in a ferry terminal in the southern Spanish port of Algeciras. The 
terminal, a non-place through which walk-on characters can drift, makes a good stage set, and it's hard to avoid 
comparisons with Beckett. Like Vladimir and Estragon, Moss and Charlie are waiting. They're waiting for Moss's 
estranged daughter Dilly to pass through on her way to or from Tangier, but they're also waiting for death.
As night falls they harangue dreadlocked travellers who they think might know Dilly, and reminisce about their lives 
of drug smuggling, dodgy real estate speculation, low-level violence and lost love. Some chapters are set in the 
The wandering rocks Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences lightly in the tale of two washed-up 
Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain . By Jon D....
past, in Ireland, London and other parts of Ryanair-accessible Europe, and describe Moss's relationship with Dilly's 
mother Cynthia, and his affairs. But most of the narrative is confined to the terminal, and the question of whether 
Dilly will ever arrive.
The partners' glory days are very much behind them. Cannabis is no longer smuggled: it's grown hydroponically in 
bedsits. The protection racket is not what it was. "The years have turned and left Maurice and Charlie behind", 
writes Barry, "the men are elegiacal, woeful, heavy in the bones. Also they are broke and grieving."
If the set-up evokes Beckett the dramatist, the language of Night Boat to Tangier is much more like that of Beckett 
the novelist. It is written in a kind of ornate pub-lyricism that casts into relief the grime and squalor of its subjects: a 
baroque High Style fused with low-life garrulousness that reminded me of the Beckett of Murphy, and of the trilogy. 
Descriptions are dense and evocative. Charlie's face "somehow has an antique look, like a court player's, medieval, 
a man who'd strum his lute for you"; Moss's "left eye is smeared and dead"; a landlord has "a papery film like 
mothskin stretched over his eyes"; the sea "guffs up a newsy froth" while a trawler, "flush with octopus", "waddles 
into port" and an SUV stops to "disgorge a unit of fat kids". The Beckettian influence is there, more explicitly, when 
Moss, exiled to London, sees, as Murphy did before him, "the lights of all the cages" of the city's lonely tenements 
go on, near the "great maw of Finsbury Park".
This is rich fare, and Barry's strident image-making can threaten to take over at times. Why need a payphone be a 
"coin phone"? Are a line of larches really "primly erect, arrogant as surgeons"? "Watch out for words most of all", 
Dilly thinks, knowingly enacting her own fears, at one point. "Watch out for ripe language - it means your words may 
be about to go off." Beckett eventually shied away from this kind of writing, as though wary of his innate fluency, 
and tried to rid his prose of its colour by composing in French before translating himself into English, but it is 
testament to Barry's ear that he is fully aware of the threat, and to his skill that his prose never reaches its sell-by 
date.
Like Murphy, Night Boat to Tangier is really about exile and loss, and about the way in which Ireland often seems 
unable to fully sustain and nourish its young. In the late 1990s, buoyed up by Celtic Tiger optimism, Cynthia and 
Moss invest his money in a swish housing development in the countryside (the builders are nervous about the 
proximity of a fairy fort, and the project founders). Later Red and Moss run away to the continent to seek their 
fortune. But abroad they only find disappointment.
For James Joyce's Stephen Dedalus, Ireland was the "sow that eats her farrow". For Moss and Charlie it is, with its 
"smiling friends" and "speaking rocks" and "sea memory", a haunted, claustrophobic place: a "wet tormented rock 
on the edge of the black Atlantic". But it is also a place that it is difficult to escape the influence of.
Jon Day is the author of 'Homing' ( John Murray) Ni ht B t t T i Night Boat to Tangier by Kevin Barry Canongate 
£14.99, 224 pages Oliver Hurst

The wandering rocks; Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences 
lightly in the tale of two washed-up Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain. 
By Jon Day
Financial Times (London, England)
June 29, 2019 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: LIFE AND ARTS;BUSINESS; Pg. 10
Length: 839 words
Body
Ni ht B t t T i Night Boat to Tangier by Kevin Barry Canongate £14.99, 224 pages Kevin Barry's first novel, City of 
Bohane, was a cinematic gangster noir set in a fictional city in the west of Ireland in a dystopian, technology-free 
future. It was a swaggering, dazzling book, studded with a kind of Hibernian version of A Clockwork Orange's 
nadsat, and it won Barry the IMPAC prize for fiction in 2013.
His second, Beatlebone, for which he won the Goldsmiths Prize in 2015, was a quieter affair, though no less 
satisfying for that. A formally inventive quest narrative, it followed John Lennon as he travelled to Dorinish, the small 
island in County Mayo he bought in 1967, where he hoped to escape from the world for a few days and indulge in 
some primal scream therapy. Barry seems always to have been interested in the tension between the smallness of 
Ireland - the "little kingdom" that Lennon describes in Beatlebone (a phrase also used in the title of Barry's first 
short-story collection) - and the expansiveness of its writing, and this tension is one that animates his third novel.
Night Boat to Tangier feels like something of a fusion of his previous books. It opens as two "fading Irish gangsters" 
- Maurice "Moss" Hearne and Charlie Redman - sit in a ferry terminal in the southern Spanish port of Algeciras. The 
terminal, a non-place through which walk-on characters can drift, makes a good stage set, and it's hard to avoid 
comparisons with Beckett. Like Vladimir and Estragon, Moss and Charlie are waiting. They're waiting for Moss's 
estranged daughter Dilly to pass through on her way to or from Tangier, but they're also waiting for death.
The wandering rocks Kevin Barry's novel wears its Beckettian influences lightly in the tale of two washed-up 
Irish gangsters at a ferry port in Spain . By Jon D....
As night falls they harangue dreadlocked travellers who they think might know Dilly, and reminisce about their lives 
of drug smuggling, dodgy real estate speculation, low-level violence and lost love. Some chapters are set in the 
past, in Ireland, London and other parts of Ryanair-accessible Europe, and describe Moss's relationship with Dilly's 
mother Cynthia, and his affairs. But most of the narrative is confined to the terminal, and the question of whether 
Dilly will ever arrive.
The partners' glory days are very much behind them. Cannabis is no longer smuggled: it's grown hydroponically in 
bedsits. The protection racket is not what it was. "The years have turned and left Maurice and Charlie behind", 
writes Barry, "the men are elegiacal, woeful, heavy in the bones. Also they are broke and grieving."
If the set-up evokes Beckett the dramatist, the language of Night Boat to Tangier is much more like that of Beckett 
the novelist. It is written in a kind of ornate pub-lyricism that casts into relief the grime and squalor of its subjects: a 
baroque High Style fused with low-life garrulousness that reminded me of the Beckett of Murphy, and of the trilogy. 
Descriptions are dense and evocative. Charlie's face "somehow has an antique look, like a court player's, medieval, 
a man who'd strum his lute for you"; Moss's "left eye is smeared and dead"; a landlord has "a papery film like 
mothskin stretched over his eyes"; the sea "guffs up a newsy froth" while a trawler, "flush with octopus", "waddles 
into port" and an SUV stops to "disgorge a unit of fat kids". The Beckettian influence is there, more explicitly, when 
Moss, exiled to London, sees, as Murphy did before him, "the lights of all the cages" of the city's lonely tenements 
go on, near the "great maw of Finsbury Park".
This is rich fare, and Barry's strident image-making can threaten to take over at times. Why need a payphone be a 
"coin phone"? Are a line of larches really "primly erect, arrogant as surgeons"? "Watch out for words most of all", 
Dilly thinks, knowingly enacting her own fears, at one point. "Watch out for ripe language - it means your words may 
be about to go off." Beckett eventually shied away from this kind of writing, as though wary of his innate fluency, 
and tried to rid his prose of its colour by composing in French before translating himself into English, but it is 
testament to Barry's ear that he is fully aware of the threat, and to his skill that his prose never reaches its sell-by 
date.
Like Murphy, Night Boat to Tangier is really about exile and loss, and about the way in which Ireland often seems 
unable to fully sustain and nourish its young. In the late 1990s, buoyed up by Celtic Tiger optimism, Cynthia and 
Moss invest his money in a swish housing development in the countryside (the builders are nervous about the 
proximity of a fairy fort, and the project founders). Later Red and Moss run away to the continent to seek their 
fortune. But abroad they only find disappointment.
For James Joyce's Stephen Dedalus, Ireland was the "sow that eats her farrow". For Moss and Charlie it is, with its 
"smiling friends" and "speaking rocks" and "sea memory", a haunted, claustrophobic place: a "wet tormented rock 
on the edge of the black Atlantic". But it is also a place that it is difficult to escape the influence of.
Jon Day is the author of 'Homing' ( John Murray)

Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears Airlines
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 27, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 457 words
Byline: ARTHUR BEESLEY
Body
Ryanair has ramped up efforts to keep the airline under majority EU ownership in a no-deal Brexit by triggering 
block purchases of shares from investors under a month-old (EURO)700m buyback scheme.
The Irish carrier's move comes amid anxiety about the rising risk of Britain crashing out of the bloc in the autumn as 
Boris Johnson, the favourite to succeed Theresa May as prime minister, pushes for a "do or die" Brexit in October 
even without a deal.
Jeremy Hunt, Mr Johnson's rival for the Conservative leadership, has also indicated that he too is willing to leave 
the EU with no agreement.
Ryanair fears a breach of its legal requirement to be majority-owned and controlled by European nationals after a 
no-deal as its share of EU shareholders would immediately drop to 45 per cent from 55 per cent without UK 
investors.
The question is one of the most complex facing airlines in the run-up to a possible no-deal, with doubt also cast 
over some carriers' supply chains for spare aircraft parts.
In a fresh bid to curtail the number of shares in the hands of non-Europeans, Ryanair yesterday rejigged the 
buyback scheme to allow block buybacks.
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears Airlines
"Any such block repurchases from UK holders of shares will, in the event of a no-deal or 'hard' Brexit, limit the 
proportionate number of shares held by or on behalf of non-EU shareholders," it said. The move will quicken the 
pace at which Ryanair's UK share base is reduced in the event of a no-deal.
Ryanair approved the share buyback only last month, saying it would run for up to 12 months. The move to allow 
block buybacks would not change the original (EURO)700m limit on the scheme, the airline said. The timing and 
actual number of shares repurchased will depend on market conditions, it added.
Ryanair said the move could "reduce the period" in which related measures to boost EU shareholdings in the 
company would be enforced.
The Dublin-based carrier has already warned UK investors that they will lose voting rights after a hard no-deal 
Brexit until Ryanair regains a 55 per cent EU majority of shareholders, something that could take as long as eight 
months.
Under measures passed by its board last March, UK shareholders will not have the right to attend, speak or vote at 
any general meeting of the company after a www.no-deal.UK nationals will not be allowed to buy Ryanair ordinary 
shares "with effect from hard Brexit day" - and when UK investors decide to sell shares in a no-deal they will be 
allowed to sell only to EU nationals.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair chief executive, has said the airline could take four months to increase its EU 
shareholding above 50 per cent with another four months required to bring the level to 55 per cent. Only then would 
Ryanair restore voting rights.
See Lex
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document

The Irish carrier's move comes amid anxiety about the rising risk of Britain crashing out of the bloc in the autumn as

no-deal as its share of EU shareholders would immediately drop to 45 per cent from 55 per cent without UK 
investors.
The question is one of the most complex facing airlines in the run-up to a possible no-deal, with doubt also cast 
over some carriers' supply chains for spare aircraft parts.
In a fresh bid to curtail the number of shares in the hands of non-Europeans, Ryanair yesterday rejigged the 
buyback scheme to allow block buybacks.
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears Airlines
"Any such block repurchases from UK holders of shares will, in the event of a no-deal or 'hard' Brexit, limit the 
proportionate number of shares held by or on behalf of non-EU shareholders," it said. The move will quicken the 
pace at which Ryanair's UK share base is reduced in the event of a no-deal.
Ryanair approved the share buyback only last month, saying it would run for up to 12 months. The move to allow 
block buybacks would not change the original (EURO)700m limit on the scheme, the airline said. The timing and 
actual number of shares repurchased will depend on market conditions, it added.
Ryanair said the move could "reduce the period" in which related measures to boost EU shareholdings in the 
company would be enforced.
The Dublin-based carrier has already warned UK investors that they will lose voting rights after a hard no-deal 
Brexit until Ryanair regains a 55 per cent EU majority of shareholders, something that could take as long as eight 
months.
Under measures passed by its board last March, UK shareholders will not have the right to attend, speak or vote at 
any general meeting of the company after a www.no-deal.UK nationals will not be allowed to buy Ryanair ordinary 
shares "with effect from hard Brexit day" - and when UK investors decide to sell shares in a no-deal they will be 
allowed to sell only to EU nationals.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair chief executive, has said the airline could take four months to increase its EU 
shareholding above 50 per cent with another four months required to bring the level to 55 per cent. Only then would 
Ryanair restore voting rights.
See Lex
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears Airlines
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 27, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 457 words
Byline: ARTHUR BEESLEY
Body
Ryanair has ramped up efforts to keep the airline under majority EU ownership in a no-deal Brexit by triggering 
block purchases of shares from investors under a month-old (EURO)700m buyback scheme.
The Irish carrier's move comes amid anxiety about the rising risk of Britain crashing out of the bloc in the autumn as 
Boris Johnson, the favourite to succeed Theresa May as prime minister, pushes for a "do or die" Brexit in October 
even without a deal.
Jeremy Hunt, Mr Johnson's rival for the Conservative leadership, has also indicated that he too is willing to leave 
the EU with no agreement.
Ryanair fears a breach of its legal requirement to be majority-owned and controlled by European nationals after a 
no-deal as its share of EU shareholders would immediately drop to 45 per cent from 55 per cent without UK 
investors.
The question is one of the most complex facing airlines in the run-up to a possible no-deal, with doubt also cast 
over some carriers' supply chains for spare aircraft parts.
In a fresh bid to curtail the number of shares in the hands of non-Europeans, Ryanair yesterday rejigged the 
buyback scheme to allow block buybacks.
Ryanair allows block buyback of shares amid Brexit fears Airlines
"Any such block repurchases from UK holders of shares will, in the event of a no-deal or 'hard' Brexit, limit the 
proportionate number of shares held by or on behalf of non-EU shareholders," it said. The move will quicken the 
pace at which Ryanair's UK share base is reduced in the event of a no-deal.
Ryanair approved the share buyback only last month, saying it would run for up to 12 months. The move to allow 
block buybacks would not change the original (EURO)700m limit on the scheme, the airline said. The timing and 
actual number of shares repurchased will depend on market conditions, it added.
Ryanair said the move could "reduce the period" in which related measures to boost EU shareholdings in the 
company would be enforced.
The Dublin-based carrier has already warned UK investors that they will lose voting rights after a hard no-deal 
Brexit until Ryanair regains a 55 per cent EU majority of shareholders, something that could take as long as eight 
months.
Under measures passed by its board last March, UK shareholders will not have the right to attend, speak or vote at 
any general meeting of the company after a www.no-deal.UK nationals will not be allowed to buy Ryanair ordinary 
shares "with effect from hard Brexit day" - and when UK investors decide to sell shares in a no-deal they will be 
allowed to sell only to EU nationals.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair chief executive, has said the airline could take four months to increase its EU 
shareholding above 50 per cent with another four months required to bring the level to 55 per cent. Only then would 
Ryanair restore voting rights.

Ryanair /Brexit: open skies blues Twitter : @FTLex
Ryanair/Brexit: open skies blues; Twitter: @FTLex
Financial Times (London, England)
June 27, 2019 Thursday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 321 words
Body
Low-cost airlines took off after the 1990s liberalisation of Europe's skies. Brexit has grounded integrationists' 
dreams. Dublin-based Ryanair is trimming accordingly. A (EURO)700m share buyback may be tweaked to reduce 
its UK shareholder base, it said yesterday. In a no-deal Brexit, that could make meeting EU ownership rules easier. 
It will not brighten shareholders' mood.
European air travel has hit serious turbulence. Overcapacity and a price war have eroded profits. Better performing 
long-haul operations have helped incumbent national carriers. They are fighting back.
Ryanair is concentrated on short haul. Its position at the top of European aviation may be at an end. Adding ballast 
is lossmaking Laudamotion, acquired recently. Ryanair's shares have underperformed Lufthansa and British 
Airways owner IAG for much of the past year. But they still trade at about 12.5 times forward earnings, a quarter 
higher than easyJet.
Brexit will intensify Ryanair's woes, especially if chaotic. Without UK shareholders, EU ownership would fall below 
the 50 per cent minimum. The (EURO)700m buyback will make scant difference, however. The sum amounts to just 
6 per cent of its market value. Perhaps the notoriously brusque company wants to show it cares about the comfort 
of shareholders, if not passengers? Yet UK shareholders still face losing voting rights.
A further threat is to EU traffic rights. In the event of a no-deal Brexit, the industry assumes regulators would keep 
aeroplanes flying. The risk of disruption is significant. Market fragmentation will become a long-term headwind. A 
quarter of Ryanair's revenues are from the UK, where its margins are higher than elsewhere.
Ryanair /Brexit: open skies blues Twitter : @FTLex
Brexit also threatens to badly disrupt the UK and continental European economies. Ryanair's buyback is therefore 
merely a sop. "This is not a time when anybody else should be buying shares," boss Michael O'Leary admitted last 
month. He is right.
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair /Brexit: open skies blues Twitter : @FTLex
Ryanair/Brexit: open skies blues; Twitter: @FTLex

Ryanair seeks to limit UK share holding with buyback amendment
Ryanair seeks to limit UK share holding with buyback amendment
Business World (Digest)
June 26, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 313 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair amended the terms of a 700 million euro share buyback on Wednesday to allow block repurchases it said 
could limit the holdings of British shareholders and ensure it remains majority EU-owned after Brexit.
Ryanair triggered contingency plans in March to restrict the voting rights of British shareholders if the UK leaves the 
European Union without a deal on future relations or quits both the EU customs union and single market in a "hard" 
Brexit scenario.
The restrictions are aimed at ensuring Europe's largest low-cost carrier remains majority EU-owned to comply with 
its licensing and flight rights.
"Ryanair advises that it is amending the terms of the arrangements to allow for shares to be repurchased by way of 
block trades from EU holders of shares," the airline said in a statement on Wednesday.
"Any such block repurchases from UK holders will, in the event of a no-deal or "hard" Brexit, limit the proportionate 
number of shares held by or on behalf of non-EU shareholders and should therefore reduce the period that the 
resolutions announced on March 11 would need to remain in place."
Ryanair Chief Financial Officer Neil Sorohan said in February that while the airline was 55 percent EU-owned, 
Britain-based shareholders controlled 20 percent of its stock. He told Reuters he expected half of those to 
redomicile to the EU in a no-deal or "hard" Brexit.
Ryanair announced the 700 million euro buyback last month, guiding that it expected to split it between 500 million 
euros of shares in underlying American Depositary Shares (ADS) and 200 million of ordinary shares, but that the 
board had discretion to revise this allocation.
Ryanair seeks to limit UK share holding with buyback amendment
It said on Wednesday that the split between ADR's and ordinary shares will be dependent on market conditions and 
legal and regulatory requirements. The programme is due to take nine to 12 months. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: July 22, 2019
End of Document
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 26, 2019 Wednesday 12:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
An airline may cite "extraordinary circumstances" in denying passengers compensation if a fuel leak on the runway 
causes a long delay, the top EU court said on Wednesday.
Passenger rights have become increasingly contested in Europe's crowded skies, and countries such as Germany 
have seen a sharp increase in complaints.
At issue is a case filed against Ryanair, which denied a passenger compensation of 250 euros (285 dollars) after a 
a flight from Italy to Belgium was delayed for four hours due to a fuel leak on the runway.
Under EU regulations, passengers may claim compensation after a delay of three hours, barring special 
circumstances.
In this case, it was aircraft fuel from another plane that had leaked on to the runway, causing a delay that "could not 
have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken within the meaning of that provision," the 
European Court of Justice (ECJ) wrote in a non-binding summary.
Such a case should be considered an extraordinary circumstance, the Luxembourg judges wrote.
The court took a similar line in April in a ruling concerning the budget airline Germanwings.
The judges concluded that passengers may be denied compensation for flight delays caused by a screw on the 
runway, if the carrier proves that it did everything possible to try to stick to the timetable - another example of a 
special circumstance.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
Load-Date: June 27, 2019
End of Document
IAG chief predicts more airline failures in 'tough' 2019 IAG chief executive Willie Walsh expects further 
European airline bankruptcies in 2019 amid "stubbornly....
IAG chief predicts more airline failures in 'tough' 2019; IAG chief executive 
Willie Walsh expects further European airline bankruptcies in 2019 amid 
"stubbornly" high fuel prices and competitive pressures in what is likely to a 
"tough" year for the sector.
Flight International
June 26, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 492 words
Body
IAG chief executive Willie Walsh expects further European airline bankruptcies in 2019 amid "stubbornly" high fuel 
prices and competitive pressures in what is likely to a "tough" year for the sector.
During a webcasted panel session at the ACI Europe annual congress in the Cypriot city of Limassol today, Walsh 
said that carriers without fuel hedges, especially those with "weak" balance sheets, were facing a "major problem".
@ACI_EUROPE
Walsh predicts that "there will be some M&A [merger and acquisition] activity" but adds: "When we talk about 
consolidation in Europe, do talk about it in the context of airlines disappearing as well. Unlike 20 years ago, I think, 
when an airline disappears it's rare to see that airline replaced."
He notes: "It's not always the case, but a lot of the capacity is now provided by airlines already in operation, which 
leaves very little space for somebody to try to come in and start up."
Ryanair chief commercial officer David O'Brien agreed. He says he expects a number of airline failures in the next 
six months in Europe, including, possibly, some "sizeable" carriers.
EasyJet chief commercial and strategy officer Robert Carey says there has as yet been little evidence of capacity 
leaving the market as a result of consolidation.
He suggest that "improvements" are still needed in Europe if it is to reach the same conditions as exist in the USA, 
where consolidation has created a "sustainable" market.
IAG chief predicts more airline failures in 'tough' 2019 IAG chief executive Willie Walsh expects further 
European airline bankruptcies in 2019 amid "stubbornly....
Overall, the airline panelists foresaw a weaker demand outlook in Europe, but detected opportunities still there for 
growth.
O'Brien describes the outlook as a "mixed bag", as uncertainty around Brexit dampens demand for air travel in the 
UK and has a knock-on effect on traffic volumes to Spain and the Mediterranean.
Walsh says demand in London is "good" and postulates, in reference to O'Brien's comments, that Brexit is perhaps 
impacting the rest of the UK more than the capital.
Aer Lingus has had a good performance in France, though Vueling's performance in that market was "weaker than 
expected", notes Walsh.
Overall the market has been "okay" in Europe, he says. A lot of capacity has been going into the market, leading to 
a "yield hit" in the first quarter, he adds.
Walsh and O'Brien both complain that Lufthansa is distorting the market in Germany and Austria. Walsh says that 
there is still demand in both countries but argues that the overcapacity which the German group has bemoaned is 
its own capacity, so in effect its airlines are "complaining about themselves".
Walsh says IAG is seeing "weakness" in Argentina and Brazil, where there are "clearly economic issues", while 
South Africa has been "weak". Europe overall has been "okay" and the demand in France and Spain robust.
Aegean Airlines chief executive Dimitris Gerogiannis says the Greek carrier is expecting a "softer" summer, with the 
market expected to "plateau" during the year. Overall, he expects the Greek market to grow by 1% in 2019.
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair Amends Share Buyback Terms in Preparation for No-Deal Brexit
Ryanair Amends Share Buyback Terms in Preparation for No-Deal Brexit
MT Newswires Live Briefs
June 26, 2019 Wednesday 5:08 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 114 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY) said pre-market Wednesday it has decided to amend the terms of its EUR700 million ($795.6 
million) share repurchase program to allow it to privately purchase shares held by UK investors and to ensure it 
remains majority EU-owned to comply with EU licensing and flight rights.
The Irish-based budget carrier said it will allow shares to be repurchased by way of block trades from EU 
shareholders. Such repurchases from UK shareholders will allow it to limit their holdings in case the UK leaves the 
EU without a deal on future relations or abandons both the EU customs union and single market in a "hard" Brexit 
scenario.
Price: 62.23, Change: -0.30, Percent Change: -0.48

Ryanair Amends Terms Of Buy-back Programme - Quick Facts
Ryanair Amends Terms Of Buy-back Programme - Quick Facts
RTT News (United States)
June 26, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 91 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) amended the terms of its share buy-back programme to allow for shares 
to be repurchased by way of block trades from EU holders of shares. The maximum consideration payable by the 
company with respect to underlying American Depositary shares remain unchanged at 700 million euros. 
 Under the amended terms of the arrangements, any block repurchases from UK holders will, in the event of a no-
deal or "hard" Brexit, limit the proportionate number of shares held by or on behalf of non-EU shareholders.        
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document
FTSE 100 Modestly Higher In Early Trade
FTSE 100 Modestly Higher In Early Trade
RTT News (United States)
June 26, 2019 Wednesday
Copyright 2019 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2019 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 157 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       U.K. stocks rose modestly on Wednesday as investors digested comments from Federal Reserve chairman 
Jerome Powell and looked ahead to the G20 meeting for directional cues. 
 The benchmark FTSE 100 was up 11 points or 0.15 percent at 7,433 after rising 0.1 percent the previous day.
 Royal Dutch Shell was up half a percent and BP Plc was rising 1 percent as oil prices jumped nearly 2 percent in 
the face of worries about U.S.-Iran relations and on data showing a large crude oil inventory draw.
 Wood Group (John) shares jumped 5.5 percent. The engineering and oilfield services provider said its performance 
in the first half was better than a year earlier.
 Low-cost airline Ryanair Holdings gained 0.6 percent after amending the terms of its share buyback program. 
 Distribution and outsourcing Group Bunzl fell over 1 percent. The company said its first-half group revenue is 
expected to have increased by approximately 4 percent.        
Load-Date: June 26, 2019
End of Document

Royal Bank of Canada Reiterates Buy Rating for Ryanair (LON:RYA)
Royal Bank of Canada Reiterates Buy Rating for Ryanair (LON:RYA)
Transcript Daily
June 24, 2019 Monday 9:08 AM EST
Copyright 2019 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Body
Jun 
24, 
2019( 
Transcript 
Daily: 
https://transcriptdaily.com 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.pngRoyal Bank of Canada reiterated their buy rating 
on shares of Ryanair (LON:RYA) in a report issued on Friday morning, Borsen Zeitung[1] reports.Shares of LON 
RYA[2] opened at GBX 991.20 ($12.95) on Friday. Ryanair has a 52 week low of GBX 9.90 ($0.13) and a 52 week 
high of GBX 1,657.50 ($21.66). The company has a quick ratio of 0.79, a current ratio of 0.93 and a debt-to-equity 
ratio of 69.88. The company has a market cap of $11.26 billion and a P/E ratio of 1,293.99. About RyanairRyanair 
Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website.See Also: Green Investing [3] [ 1]: 
https://www.boersen-zeitung.de/index.php?l=11..._filter=investor...ter=investor...e_number=1/ [ 2]:            
https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/LON/RYA/price-target/ [ 3]:            https://www.marketbeat.com/financial-
terms/what-is-green-investing/

European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
June 21, 2019 Friday 10:45 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 233 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.51% higher at 1,053.33 on the BNY Mellon 
Europe Select ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biotech firm Forward Pharma (FWP) and online dating site operator 
Spark Networks (LOV), which rose 2.7% and 2.4% respectively. They were followed by telecommunications 
company VEON (VEON) and oil and gas company Eni (E), which were up 1.8% each.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by 3D printer company Materialise (MTLS) and pharmaceutical 
company Ascendis Pharma (ASND), which fell 2.6% and 2.5% respectively. They were followed by software firm 
Talend (TLND) and biopharmaceutical company MorphoSys (MOR), which lost 2% and 1.6%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by oil and gas company Royal Dutch Shell (RDS-A) and educational 
publishing company Pearson (PSO), which rose 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical company Akari Therapeutics (AKTX) and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which were up  
0.5% each.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical company NuCana (NCNA) and specialty 
pharmaceutical company Motif Bio (MTFB), which fell 10.4% and 6.4% respectively. They were followed by cruise 
line operator Carnival (CUK) and pharmaceutical firm Avadel (AVDL), which lost 4.6% and 2.5%.
Price: 0.96, Change: +0.03, Percent Change: +2.74
Load-Date: June 22, 2019
End of Document

Malta Air is latest to join Ryanair stable Low-cos t carrie r say s mov e wil l se e i t ad d No r t h Afric a service s 
an d hel p islan d become southern Euro....
Malta Air is latest to join Ryanair stable; Low-cos t carrie r say s mov e wil l 
se e i t ad d No r t h Afric a service s an d hel p islan d become southern 
European transit hub
Flight International
June 18, 2019
Copyright 2019 DVV Media International Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 274 words
Body
Ryanair has detailed plans to set up a unit in Malta, adding to its growing stable of airlines.
The Irish carrier will move six Malta-based Boeing 737s into start-up Malta Air and plans to grow the fleet based in 
the country to 10 aircraft within three years.
In addition, 200 crew will move to local Maltese contracts, and Ryanair says it plans to create 350 jobs over three 
years.
Ryanair says the investment will give it access to North Africa markets from Malta. The Maltese government had on 
9 June disclosed an outline of the plans, saying that the Ryanair initiative would help develop the island nation into 
a southern European transit hub.
“Malta Air will proudly fly the Maltese name and flag to over 60 destinations across Europe and North Africa as we 
look to grow our Maltese-based fleet, routes, traffic and jobs over the next three years,” states Ryanair chief 
executive Michael O’Leary.
The budget carrier will also add to its Maltese air operator’s certificate dozens of Ryanair aircraft currently based 
across France, Germany and Italy. The move will allow employees to pay income tax in those countries, rather than 
in Ireland, where the aircraft are currently registered.
“We look forward to working closely with the Maltese authorities over the coming years as we hope to add over 50 
more aircraft to the Maltese register,” adds O’Leary. Ryanair says it hopes to complete the investment in Malta Air 
by the end of June.
Malta Air is set to join Buzz, Laudamotion, Ryanair UK and the principal Ryanair operation within the group. Ryanair 
had previously set up an IAG-style structure earlier this year to manage its operating units.
Malta Air is latest to join Ryanair stable Low-cos t carrie r say s mov e wil l se e i t ad d No r t h Afric a service s 
an d hel p islan d become southern Euro....
Load-Date: June 18, 2019
End of Document

Lufthansa : whingeing it Twitter : @FTLex
Lufthansa: whingeing it; Twitter: @FTLex
Financial Times (London, England)
June 18, 2019 Tuesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 10
Length: 376 words
Body
Are we there yet? European airline shareholders will empathise with overtired infants trapped in economy on 
delayed flights. Another profit warning by Lufthansa pushed its shares 11 per cent lower yesterday.
Other European airlines had similar falls. Lufthansa's market value has dropped almost half since 2018. Yet the end 
of the journey is still not in sight.
Lufthansa blamed fierce competition, especially in its German and Austrian home markets. Eurowings, its budget 
airline that accounts for 12 per cent of revenues, racked up losses. As in European banking, fragmentation and 
overcapacity have eroded profits in European short-haul airlines. Shares in IAG, owner of British Airways, Ryanair, 
and easyJet as well as Lufthansa have underperformed sickly European bank stocks over the past year.
Airlines have sought to restrain supply. Growth in European short-haul capacity should fall below 3 per cent in the 
third quarter, the lowest for four years, Barclays reckons. Outright cuts may be needed. Lufthansa's warning 
indicates that demand has fallen short of expectations. Germany's economy has stalled. Brexit will dog European 
airlines at least until the winter.
Before then, action on capacity is unlikely. Bookings are already in place. Meanwhile, price wars will intensify. 
Lufthansa says that it will "vigorously defend" market shares. That was a riposte to Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary's 
promise of "painful" price cuts to drive out rivals.
Consolidation through mergers would be a way out. Lufthansa's balance sheet is strong. But splashy acquisitions 
risk further alienating shareholders. Lufthansa is eyeing Thomas Cook's German airline business. Fixing Eurowings 
should be its immediate priority.
Lufthansa : whingeing it Twitter : @FTLex
Lufthansa's shares trade at a low-altitude multiple of just 4 times forward earnings. IAG and Air France, less 
exposed to European short haul, are barely higher. Brighter global economic skies ahead would help.
Ominously, however, Lufthansa also warned on profits in its cargo operations. The unit accounts for just 7 per cent 
of revenues but as global economic worries rise, it foreshadows weakness in the long haul business, which has 
held up so far.
Fewer packages in the hold are another reason Lufthansa's shareholder patience will be tested.
Load-Date: June 17, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa : whingeing it

Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount
Financial Times (London, England)
June 18, 2019 Tuesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 537 words
Byline: JANINA CONBOYE
Body
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount JANINA CONBOYE - LONDON Shares in Lufthansa 
dropped 12 per cent and weighed on its rivals after the German airline lowered its profit outlook for the second time 
this year. Despite strong business on transatlantic and Asian routes, the airline's European short-haul market, 
which includes its low-cost airline Eurowings, continues to face pressure from other carriers as they battle to win 
passengers. There is mounting evidence that conditions in the European airline industry are worsening after several 
carriers warned they were facing tough trading conditions. 
Ryanair and easyJet both issued profit warnings this year. Lufthansa expects its margin on adjusted earnings 
before interest and tax (ebit) to be between 5.5 per cent and 6.5 per cent, down from a previously predicted 6.5 per 
cent to 8 per cent. It said this would produce an adjusted ebit figure of (EURO)2bn to (EURO)2.4bn. This also 
factors in a (EURO)550m increase in fuel costs, despite a recent decline in the oil price. The profit warning dragged 
down Europe's other big airlines. Ryanair shares fell 6 per cent, easyJet was down 5 per cent and Air France 
slipped 5 per 'Company [is] seemingly unable to know where to focus its capital - and where not to' cent. Adrian 
Yanoshik, analyst at Berenberg, said that "primarily it's a shorthaul average fare pricing issue that's spooked 
people", reflecting overcapacity in the the European short-haul market. He also said that as Europe's largest airline, 
Lufthansa was a "canary in a coal mine", driving sentiment in the sector. At Eurowings, revenues are expected to 
decline significantly in the second quarter. For the full year, Lufthansa forecast a decrease at a mid-single-digit rate 
citing that "the progress in streamlining the Eurowings cost base is also slower than expected". "The Eurowings 
management has resolved upon further turnround measures which it will present shortly," Lufthansa said. But 
according to Mr Yanoshik the company has not as yet "offered up any specifics". The airline said it expected the 
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount
European market to remain challenging for the remainder of the year. But RBC Capital Markets said in a note that it 
remained "astonished" that Lufthansa continues to vigorously defend its market share, when "it is increasingly clear 
to us it seems to have neither the cost base nor product/price mix to do so without destroying shareholder value". 
RBC sees little relief for the shares until Lufthansa "rethinks this value-destructive strategy". RBC also noted that it 
found it hard to blame Eurowings' costs on external factors saying that "financial control/management issues are 
now compounding the impact of a company seemingly unable to know where to focus its capital - and where not 
to". Lufthansa Cargo has also been hit by weaker demand between Europe and Asia and expects flat revenue in 
2019. Analysts at Bernstein noted that the decline in air freight demand raised more worries as it could foreshadow 
a slower business environment. Lufthansa made an adjusted loss of (EURO)336m before interest and tax in the 
first three months of 2019, compared with an adjusted profit of (EURO)52m in same quarter last year. See Lex
Load-Date: June 17, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount Airlines
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
June 18, 2019 Tuesday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2019 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 521 words
Byline: JANINA CONBOYE
Body
Shares in Lufthansa dropped 12 per cent and weighed on its rivals after the German airline lowered its profit outlook 
for the second time this year.
Despite strong business on transatlantic and Asian routes, the airline's European short-haul market, which includes 
its low-cost airline Eurowings, continues to face pressure from other carriers as they battle to win passengers.
There is mounting evidence that conditions in the European airline industry are worsening after several carriers 
warned they were facing tough trading conditions. Ryanair and easyJet both issued profit warnings this year.
Lufthansa expects its margin on adjusted earnings before interest and tax (ebit) to be between 5.5 per cent and 6.5 
per cent, down from a previously predicted 6.5 per cent to 8 per cent.
It said this would produce an adjusted ebit figure of (EURO)2bn to (EURO)2.4bn. This also factors in a 
(EURO)550m increase in fuel costs, despite a recent decline in the oil price.
The profit warning dragged down Europe's other big airlines. Ryanair shares fell 6 per cent, easyJet was down 5 
per cent and Air France slipped 5 per cent. Adrian Yanoshik, analyst at Berenberg, said that "primarily it's a 
shorthaul average fare pricing issue that's spooked people", reflecting overcapacity in the the European short-haul 
market.
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount Airlines
He also said that as Europe's largest airline, Lufthansa was a "canary in a coal mine", driving sentiment in the 
sector.
At Eurowings, revenues are expected to decline significantly in the second quarter. For the full year, Lufthansa 
forecast a decrease at a mid-single-digit rate citing that "the progress in streamlining the Eurowings cost base is 
also slower than expected".
"The Eurowings management has resolved upon further turnround measures which it will present shortly," 
Lufthansa said. But according to Mr Yanoshik the company has not as yet "offered up any specifics".
The airline said it expected the European market to remain challenging for the remainder of the year.
But RBC Capital Markets said in a note that it remained "astonished" that Lufthansa continues to vigorously defend 
its market share, when "it is increasingly clear to us it seems to have neither the cost base nor product/price mix to 
do so without destroying shareholder value". RBC sees little relief for the shares until Lufthansa "rethinks this value-
destructive strategy".
RBC also noted that it found it hard to blame Eurowings' costs on external factors saying that "financial 
control/management issues are now compounding the impact of a company seemingly unable to know where to 
focus its capital - and where not to".
Lufthansa Cargo has also been hit by weaker demand between Europe and Asia and expects flat revenue in 2019. 
Analysts at Bernstein noted that the decline in air freight demand raised more worries as it could foreshadow a 
slower business environment.
Lufthansa made an adjusted loss of (EURO)336m before interest and tax in the first three months of 2019, 
compared with an adjusted profit of (EURO)52m in same quarter last year.
See Lex
'Company [is] seemingly unable to know where to focus its capital - and where not to'
Load-Date: June 17, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount Airlines
Lufthansa lowers profit forecast as short-haul woes mount; Airlines

Body
Shares in Lufthansa dropped 12 per cent and weighed on its rivals after the German airline lowered its profit outlook 
for the second time this year.

its low-cost airline Eurowings, continues to face pressure from other carriers as they battle to win passengers.

warned they were facing tough trading conditions. Ryanair and easyJet both issued profit warnings this year.
