European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
May 3, 2019 Friday 11:20 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.48% higher at 1,060.24 on the BNY Mellon 
Europe Select ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by hotel booking site Trivago (TRVG), and 3D printer maker voxeljet 
(VJET), which rose 4.8% and 3% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical firm argenx (ARGX), and 
3D printer  company Materialise (MTLS), which were up 2% and 1.8%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by pharmaceutical firm Novo Nordisk (NVO), and internet browser 
company Opera (OPRA), which lost 2% and 1.7% respectively. They were followed by telecommunications 
operator Orange (ORAN), and financial services firm Credit Suisse (CS), which were off 1% and 0.7%. 
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by bank HSBC (HSBC), and medical device maker Smith & Nephew 
(SNN), which climbed 2.8% and 2.6% respectively. They were followed by mining company Rio Tinto (RIO), and 
pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca (AZN), which were up 2.1% and 1.4%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biotech firm Autolus Therapeutics (AUTL), and software company 
Endava (DAVA), which fell 3.4% and 1.4% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company Amarin 
(AMRN), and airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which were off 1.4% and 0.8%.
Price: 4.63, Change: +0.29, Percent Change: +6.68
Load-Date: May 4, 2019
End of Document
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After 
M&A Woe
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
May 3, 2019 Friday 5:42 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 788 words
Body
 Earnings were in focus over the past week in the consumer services sector, with J Sainsbury posting some good 
figures following its failed merger with Asda the week prior and Whitbread issuing its first annual results since 
selling its Costa Coffee chain to Coca-Cola.
Grocer Sainsbury's on Wednesday reported a 42% drop in pretax profit for the 52 weeks to March 9, not helped by 
almost GBP400 million of extra charges related to the aborted Asda merger, pension costs, and an overhaul of its 
banking platform. 
Revenue was up, though, by 1.9%, and underlying pretax profit beat expectations. Sainsbury's returned 11 pence 
to shareholders, up 7.8% year-on-year and ahead of consensus. 
The announcement came a day after Kantar said the UK's grocery sector picked up some pace in the 12 weeks to 
April 21, boosted by Easter spending, with Sainsbury's reclaiming second place from Asda in terms of market 
share. 
Turning to non-food retail, clothing and homewares chain Next on Wednesday beat its own sales expectations 
thanks to warmer weather at the end of April.
Sales in the thirteen weeks April 27 climbed 4.5%, ahead of expectations of a 3.2% rise, though Next did warn not 
to expect similar performance in the rest of the year. 
Fashion and homeware retailer N Brown on Thursday sunk to an annual loss after a profit, due to almost GBP150 
million of exceptional charges, treble a year prior. 
Revenue was broadly flat, with the Jacamo-owner saying performance was "solid" in the 52 weeks to March 2. 
However, it cut its annual dividend 50%, to 7.1p. 
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
Looking at the wider UK retail sphere, on Friday research firm BDO said good weather, the school holidays, and a 
late Easter failed to soothe the UK's suffering high streets.
High street retail sales fell 0.4% in April, BDO said, the third month of decline in 2019 already, while there has been 
next to no growth over the past 15 months. 
On Wednesday, shop price inflation was shown to have fallen to 0.4% in April from 0.9% in March by the BRC-
Nielsen Shop Price Index. The slowdown was caused by a more than doubling of the number of discounted 
products as retailers try to boost sales. 
There was also an initial public offering announced in the retail sector, with luxury retailer Watches of Switzerland 
announcing a plan to float in London.
The firm, which sells top watch brands such as Rolex, Tag Heuer, Omega, and Patek Philippe, did not provide 
many details, but did say it would offer both new shares and allow existing shareholders - primarily investment 
funds managed by an affiliate of Apollo Global Management - to sell theirs. 
On Thursday, budget airline Ryanair reported a 10% rise in April passenger numbers, including Austrian airline 
Lauda, reaching 13.0 million. 
On the same day, central and eastern Europe-focused peer Wizz Air posted 19% traffic growth, with passenger 
numbers reaching 3.3 million. 
Outside of the UK, German airline Lufthansa on Tuesday posted a significantly widened first quarter net loss, 
reaching EUR342 million from just EUR39 million a year prior. 
Lufthansa blamed the wider loss on a sharp rise in fuel costs and a deterioration in unit revenue in Europe. Overall 
revenue rose 3% to EUR7.89 billion. 
A week-long strike by SAS pilots ended on Thursday, though not before the Scandinavian airline had to cancel 
4,000 flights. 
The labour action was over concerns about scheduling, job security, and salaries, and affected around 380,000 
passengers. 
Moving into hospitality, Intercontinental Hotels Group on Friday reported subdued revenue per available room 
growth, rising 0.3% in the first quarter.
In the Americas, the figure rose 0.8%, with performance strong in the US, Mexico, and Colombia. 
Premier Inn-owner Whitbread on Tuesday posted a steep drop, 39%, in pretax profit for its year ended February 28, 
though it did rise 1.2% underlying. 
Whitbread booked GBP178 million in extra costs, much of which were due to its sale of Costa Coffee to Coca-Cola. 
Whitbread cut its annual dividend to 99.65p from 101.15p a year prior, and it also warned on weak revenue per 
room in the UK going forward. 
Moving to restaurants, brewer and pub owner Greene King on Tuesday guided for a rise in profit in its recently 
ended year, following solid sales growth.
Greene King said sales rose 2.9% ahead of the UK pub market for its year ended April 29, with trading over Easter 
strong. Profit before tax and exceptional items for the year to be in the range of GBP244 million and GBP247 
million, slightly ahead year-on-year.
On the same day, fast-food firm McDonald's said it had a strong start to 2019, despite a slight decline in net income 
and revenue.
CONSUMER SERVICES SECTOR REVIEW: Sainsbury Results Cheer After M&A Woe
Revenue fell 3.6% in the first quarter of 2019 due to refranchising, while net income dipped 3.4%. 
Load-Date: May 4, 2019
End of Document

European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
May 2, 2019 Thursday 10:41 AM EST
Copyright 2019 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 238 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.84% lower at 1,057.32 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by computer hardware maker Logitech (LOGI) and biotech firm 
MorphoSys (MOR), which rose 4.3% and 2.8% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical company 
Cellectis (CLLS) and Deutsche Bank (DB), which were up 1.9% and 1.7%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by semiconductor company Sequans Communications (SQNS) and 
biopharmaceutical company Genfit (GNFT), which fell 5.9% and 2.4% respectively. They were followed by biotech 
company Zealand Pharma (ZEAL) and online dating site operator Spark Networks (LOV), which were off 2% each.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company Amarin (AMRN) and medical device 
maker Smith & Nephew (SNN), which climbed 2.9% and 2.8% respectively. They were followed by public relations 
firm WPP (WPP) and biopharmaceutical company Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which rose 2.3% and 2.0%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by information and analytics provider RELX PLC (RELX) and tobacco 
and consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI), which fell 1.6% and 1.3% respectively. They were 
followed by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY) and cruise line operator Carnival (CUK), which dropped 1.2% and 
1.1%.
Price: 40.17, Change: +1.72, Percent Change: +4.47
Load-Date: May 3, 2019
End of Document
